title: Opening Party
description:
This will include food, drink, opening announcements & orientation, and our illustrious Show One Thing Show where we all get to know a little bit more about each other.

LOCATION: 721 Broadway, 4th Floor South, New York, NY. Take the left elevators to the 4th Floor

WHAT'S HAPPENING:

6PM - Doors open. Check in. Food, drink, and mingling. 

7PM - Camp Orientation. Everything you need to know about ITP Camp.

7:30PM - Show One Thing Show!

user.name: Arielle Hein
user.about:
I am your Camp Coordinator! I'd love to help you with anything Camp related.

I graduated from ITP in 2015 and am currently working as an Instructor in the ATLAS Institute at the University of Colorado in Boulder.

I am most excited about exploring the link between technology and human values - social, cultural, experiential. I build physical things, and web-based things. I also like connecting physical things to the web. And I'm endlessly curious about notions of time, and building clocks!

user.name: Nicole B
user.about:
Currently working on the 10th Fl - NYU Tisch Film & TV Grads & Upper class-men.

I help teach students (and troubleshoot) how to use Avid, Premiere Pro, DaVinci Resolve, etc.
I also color grade on the side - currently waiting on a full length feature doc about Manhattan Plaza for performing artists!

Though it's a great job, there's no room for growth/ promotion, and little more I can learn.
Since I've always had an intense interest in all things computer/ gaming/ coding/ Arduinos/ etc, I'm taking ITP Camp for an intro into the field and, hopefully, a new career direction.

user.name: jparada
user.about: Former ITP student in the 90s. Did my time in the NYC internet bubble and then became a professor in Philadelphia, PA.

user.name: Dan Kawasaki
user.about:
I'm Head of Visual and User Design at UltraLinq Healthcare Solutions. It is a cloud-based storage and workflow solution for remote diagnostics and care. Trust me when I say that this space is a fast-growing and exciting field to be involved in right now.

I was the former Director of User Experience at Ogilvy for nearly ten years and have over 20+ years of expertise in the field. I also teach at Parsons School of Design@The New School and the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

user.name: Adam H
user.about:
I'm a creative taking the summer to transition my career from traditional design to digital practices. 

I've spent the last few years developing brand identities for huge corporations and now I want to turn my attention to more purpose driven work as well as follow the fun I've had with code to develop a more robust skill set.

user.name: Carolanne Patterson
user.about: I am a visual artist and also currently teach metal-smithing and digital fabrication using the laser cutter for 3D fabrication sculpture. I sometimes combine the two disciplines. I work with mixed media in my studio, making motorized sculptures powered by solar panels, large format photographs that I paint on, and wearables.  I would like to learn more about electronics, power and arduino. I lived in NYC for many years and now I live in CT.

user.name: Anthony B
user.about:
I’m particularly excited to work on projects that explore some of our unconscious biases and leverage technology to help us step outside our own bubbles. Slightly outside my professional expertise, I’d also like to explore leading sessions exploring mental health, abstaining from technology, whimsical hacks, and falling in love with open source.

I’m a senior software engineer at Dia&Co, a startup revolutionizing the often overlooked plus-size fashion industry. As a full-stack web developer, I am responsible for guiding the development of features and products to completion – including defining the scope of projects, identifying and researching project unknowns, interacting in teams to narrow or change the scope of projects, defining and holding the team accountable to deadlines. I spend most of my days coding in ruby and javascript (as well as geeking out about programming languages and new technologies =P).

I'm a designer, technologist, and teacher. I'm interested in dancing, food, natural language processing, generative silliness, awkward interactions.

Currently, I'm working to improve access to health and human services with the NYC Mayor's Office for Economic Opportunity as a product manager.

Former ITP Camp Counselor + ITP alum.

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

user.name: George Gally
user.about: Media artist and designer. Interested in sound and motion reactive systems. Mostly use Javascript.

user.name: Pablo Ricaurte Llorente
user.about:
Hi, my name is Pablo, I´m from Colombia and my background is a degree in industrial design in Bogotá, DC.
I work creating interactive light installations from waste material in party´s, concerts, nightclubs and all kind of events and venues for the entertainments industry. I have designed booths for many dj´s that have come to my city. This is my first time at the ITP, it looks amazing! At the moment I´m working with LED fixtures built from "trash" and mix the system through the sound so you can feel immersed in a synesthetic environment, like an audio/visual system that goes with the frequencies of the audio. The waste material fixtures are made out of up-cycling products and converting them into LED fixtures in to screens, where the users can play with tablets, displays, cameras and other kind of sensors. I´d love to teach everybody how to solder, plug and program LEDs, create visual content that flows with the music and how to build fixtures out of waste material, to create new products.

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

user.name: Darren Solomon
user.about: composer, musician, excited to return for my second year, let's make stuff!

user.name: Graham Starr
user.about: I am a visual and data journalist specializing in [experimental features](https://www.theatlantic.com/timeline/) and [interactive projects](https://www.theatlantic.com/projects/inside-jobs), currently on staff at [WIRED magazine](https://www.wired.com/).

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

user.name: Mark Lam
user.about: I experiment with interactive technology and traditional handcraft. My practice seeks to disrupt the notion that there is a place for everything and everything is in its place. More simply put: if the Medium is the Message, what is the Message and how can it be reinterpreted?

user.name: Baaria
user.about:
I’m a virtual reality enthusiast, avid book reader of all topics, and a lifelong learner. My interests include VR/AR, storytelling, and curious thought experiments about the future of technology. My favorite question always starts with "What if..." and I often try to follow up with the answer.

I create fun and weird experiences that challenge the reality we live in with VR/AR. My approach to virtual and augmented reality is more artistically inclined, with emphasis on experience design.

I’m also an aspiring lighthouse owner, coffee drinker, and writer. I like to-do lists, cats, and people who hire me. Currently, my favorite color is green.

If you’re interested in virtual and augmented reality or collaborating to create an experience, I’d love to hear from you.

user.name: Divya Gaitonde
user.about: Currently a UX/Product Designer at MSK Data Products where build digital tools that leverage data and machine learning to prevent, control and cure cancer

user.name: RJ
user.about: Dan Shiffman's channel brought me here.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

user.name: Ann B
user.about: Ann Bennett is an Emmy nominated documentary filmmaker and multimedia producer. She produced the NAACP Image Award winning PBS feature documentary, "Through A Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People" as well as the multi-platform community engagement initiative, "Digital Diaspora Family Reunion" (DDFR). Bennett's film credits include; 'Citizen King' and 'Fisk Jubilee Singers' for the PBS series "American Experience", 'Hymn for Alvin Ailey' for "Dance in America", and the award winning PBS mini-series; 'Africans in America' and 'America's War on Poverty'.  Bennett is a graduate of Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and Harvard College.

user.name: Claire Wang
user.about: I worked both as a language teacher and a UX designer. I have already got a master’s degree in Applied Linguistics back in China, now I’m pursuing another one in the intersection of education, design and technology. I want to explore the possibility that the technologies could bring about and I'm interested in brainstorming and making stuff together with people.

user.name: Christina M.
user.about: I am in infosec/tech nerd and come with a background in enterprise identity and access/information security. A couple of years ago I also co-founded a community for women of color in tech and created an open source collection of stock photos to signal boost visual representation and diversity in the industry. I am currently a senior program manager at Microsoft (new job yay!) but when I am not at work or spending time with my family, I really enjoy taking classes, attending cryptoparties, Twitter'ing and enjoying this great city of ours. I also love to advise, speak and mentor people, communities, and organizations who have an interest in technology.

user.name: Kate Yourke
user.about: Assistant Director for the Arts at the Lang School, teaching Creative Lab and Tinkering classes. Founded the non-profit Make: STEAM to present workshops, professional development, and the STEAM WORKS Festival of Curiosity.

user.name: Jared van Fleet
user.about: i'm into it

user.name: chad ruble
user.about: I love ITP camp and have attended every year since it started 6 (wow is that right?) years ago.  I begin with huge ambitions for finalizing projects that were initiated or conceptualized years ago, but always find myself taking inspiring detours. I can't wait to meet new campers and reconnect with returning ones. I am a dad of two and entrepreneur who started Tapgram.com, a visual-based social network for people who have trouble with language and keyboards).  This year, I am curious about all things mixed reality.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

comments.body: Hi Kate！I am an ITP 2017 camper. How can I RSVP your session？

title: All Camp Social Hour: Porcupine Workshop & Spiky Cocktail Hour
description:
What happens when everyone at a cocktail party is covered in spikes? 
 
You are cordially invited to participate in a micro workshop + social experiment.

Porcupine Workshop + Spiky Cocktail Hour
+ 6:00-6:30 PM: Workshop - constructing Porcupine wearables
+ 6:30-7:30 PM: Spiky Cocktail Hour -  with spiky food & spiky drinks
 
We will spend the first 30 minutes assembling Porcupine wearables - wearable, spiky body-extensions constructed of cardboard and fasteners that allow you to take up more space. They can be used to expand your footprint and sometimes your personal expression. This design TBD, but check out a previous example here:

 http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-Make-a-Porcupine-Vest/
 
Materials will be provided and no previous experience is required.

The remaining time will consist of an elegant and prickly cocktail hour. Adorned in our spikes with an extended sense of embodiment we will eat, drink, and interact. 

Photos and video of the festivities will be collected and shared. Spike and/or cocktail themed attire is strongly encouraged.

Please RSVP by June 11th so we have adequate time to prepare the necessary materials!

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

title: How to Create a ChatBot with RiveScript
description: This session is a collaboration with [TheWriter](http://www.thewriter.com/).  We'll discuss a brief history of "chatbots" (computer programs designed to have a text-based conversation with a human user) and examine the landscape of tools and frameworks for creating them. We'll then build our own chatbots using [RiveScript](https://www.rivescript.com/), a simple scripting language with a friendly, easy to learn syntax (no programming experience necessary!). After we build some simple chatbots, we'll look at how RiveScript can be integrated in a web application with JavaScript.

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

title: Make Everything Feel: Really Simple Touch / Proximity Sensors From Natural Objects
description:
Plug 1 wire into your arduino, clip it to something kinda conductive ( a plant, a puddle, or a bike handle). and that's all you need  for interactive projects!
.Capacitive Touch sensing is one of the simplest, and most fun ways to make almost anything in the world into a touch sensitive controller! This is how things like touch lamps work, and the basic sensing in fun kits like the Makey Makey: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfQqh7iCcOU

However, most folks tend to start their capacitive touch sensing projects using (what I consider) outdated methods. Old-fashioned captouch tends to be noisy, needing constant recalibration, and really only works well when the electronics are grounded. It also tends to give best readings on just a binary "Touched or not" kind of basis. Most importantly old style cap-touch tends to use a minimum of 2 wires and a big resistor to make your interaction work.

Using ADC captouch, instead frees us from so many problems, and gives us the smallest amount of materials necessary to make cool interesting sensors! Places like Hackteria started looking to this method as an improvement over the Makey Makey (http://www.hackteria.org/projects/cocomake7/), and we can talk about the basic theory while we make them!

WHAT WILL WE DO

First we will start off building and programming our devices. Then we will move outdoors and test out and explore the touch-sensitive properties of many items in nature and public areas nearby. Debugging with cap-touch is fun and lets you explore the material properties of whatever you connect it to. Toward the end, we will refine our projects into interesting interactive demos for public interaction.

title: Ant Collecting! Checking out ants
description:
Ants are super cool! Maybe you want to start your own ant farm! Maybe you want to work ants into your next design project? Maybe you just want to catch and release while studying their intricate worlds up close! Maybe you want to understand deeply why they keep coming into your kitchen no matter how many foragers get squished?

WHAT WILL WE DO
We will start walking around some nearby nature-y areas hunting for ants. They are quite ubiquitous so they can be fun and easy to do projects with. We will discuss and test out different methods for capturing workers or even whole colonies. We will even discuss ways that scientists keep track of specific ants (e.g ant painting - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uAQ5IKVpysc ) Finally we will demonstrate some ways you can sense their movement digitally and feed this into interactive systems!

title: Outdoor Hacking: Practice Doing Programming and Electronics Outdoors!
description:
Are you working on an electronics project? Programming project? Sick of being cooped up inside? Well come on out, rain or shine, and build in the wild with us! Ill set up a "wild lab," with modular worksurfaces, tarps, and portable workshop tools all set for you to solder, debug, program, and whatever you need. Feel free to treat it as an open lab, and stop by for a bit or longer and work on your projects, and we can talk about infrastructure that frees you from the lab!

I'll give tips on how to handle common challenges when wild-hacking!

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

title: (Talk) Hacking the Wild and Weird: Physical Computing Meets Reality TV
description:
I ended up starring in an international television show called "Hacking the Wild" release on Discovery's multiple networks. They saw me building electronics in the wild with scientists, and ended up with a quirky show where I am forced to survive by constantly pulling apart laptops.

I'll give a fun talk that pulls back the curtain and goes over the history of this weird TV show, and all the strangenesses that occur during a high-stakes, intense film production that basically relies on interaction design. I'll share clips (many never before seen) from my experience, and do a Q and A about some really strange experiences. 

This talk is a must see for anyone wanting survival tricks and tips when being kidnapped by hollywood producers to work on a survival show.
tag_list: TV, talk, physical computing, interaction design, weird hollywood people

title: (Talk) Digital Naturalism: Design Framework for Working with Computers and Creatures in the Wild
description:
I'll be giving a talk about my research into "Digital Naturalism." (Introduction with examples here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Q-HbBKC2i4 )

Digital Naturalism investigates the role that Digital Media can play for Biological Field Work. It looks to uphold the naturalistic values of wilderness exploration, while investigating the new abilities offered by digital technology.

In particular, Digital Naturalism looks at how digital media can be used to explore animal behaviors situated in their natural context. Most recently, this research has been carried out directly in the field in the form of Hiking Hackathons. 

I'll share my past and recent experiences hacking in the wilderness and future plans. Then we'll have a quick question and answer session!

title: Near-Perfect Web Design Transfers Using Grids and Sass
description:
In the design-comp-to-website translation, in which a designer’s comprehensive design is converted into a working website, the final result is oftentimes far from the original design. Using Sass with grids heightens the chances that the designer’s intention is translated faithfully into a website.

We’ll discuss how to use [The Modular Grid](https://github.com/code-warrior/the-modular-grid), an extension for Chrome, to achieve near-pixel perfect translations of design comps to web pages.

Slides forthcoming.
tag_list: css 3, grids, the modular grid, sass, comp, design

user.name: Berlina
user.about:
I am a hardware maker turned **front-end web developer with specialization in Javascript canvas APi**(p5.js alike). I do contact improvisation in the past 5 years and would like to discover a way to **sharpen our built-in senses**. For me, it is a way to better locate yourself in physical and increasingly overwhelming virtual world. Let's all take a deep breathe together first.  

I have made many different things/prototypes along the way of learning new skills.
I built hypnotized brainwave-interactive light installation(failed!), sound controlled flappy bird to embarrass yourself in public as an ice-breaker, digital scratch card with any amount money your want (thx to generated art), and collaborated with local artists to make Ebay(Chinese version) plug-in to hack product recommendation algorithm and  interactive Facebook wall you can read in an elevator. 

Feel free to check out my work [here](https://berlinali.github.io/work/) and talk to me in the camp.

title: Game Design Lab 101
description: What makes a game fun? Can it also be thought-provoking or educational? This workshop will involve a crash course in game design theory, a little discussion on weird games, an exercise in designing your own, non-digital games, and lots of play!

leader_users.name: Sharang Biswas
leader_users.about: Sharang Biswas is a game designer, writer and artist based in New York City. His interactive performance projects include TREASON and THE INSTITUTE at The Brick, and BASIC PRINCIPLES OF INCANTATION at the Denny Gallery. He has also worked on gaming and game design with institutions such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of the Moving Image, the Montclair Art Museum and the Harrison Public Library. His boardgame MAD SCIENCE FOUNDATION was published by Cryptozoic Entertainment last year, and his writing on games, media and interaction has appeared on Zam and Kill Screen. Sharang regularly teaches game design and tech skills at various high school in the NYC area, and to special needs students with the nonprofit Tech Kids Unlimited. He holds Masters from ITP and a Bachelors of Engineering from Dartmouth.

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

title: Show-One-Thing-Show
description:
A hybrid talent show / open-mic / show-and-tell extravaganza! Each person will have **ONE MINUTE + ONE SLIDE to present ONE THING**

For example, you might want to share:

A project you made  
A place you traveled  
A hobby you have  
A dance you know  
A song you wrote  
A thing you ate  

There are only 2 rules for the slide: it must include your NAME, and it cannot include any video content.

It will be a fun opportunity to get to know each other better, we hope everyone will sign up to share :)

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

user.name: Vanessa Rosa

Vanessa has worked as project coordinator for different organizations and is an illustrator and art director for Viajante do Tempo publishing company. Vanessa has a deep interest in collaboration projects and in understanding other cultures and cities. She has already proposed and participated in mural paintings, exhibitions and other projects in different countries across South and North America, Europe and this year she's heading to Africa for the first time.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

user.name: Ann B
user.about: Ann Bennett is an Emmy nominated documentary filmmaker and multimedia producer. She produced the NAACP Image Award winning PBS feature documentary, "Through A Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People" as well as the multi-platform community engagement initiative, "Digital Diaspora Family Reunion" (DDFR). Bennett's film credits include; 'Citizen King' and 'Fisk Jubilee Singers' for the PBS series "American Experience", 'Hymn for Alvin Ailey' for "Dance in America", and the award winning PBS mini-series; 'Africans in America' and 'America's War on Poverty'.  Bennett is a graduate of Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and Harvard College.

user.about: Vanessa Rosa is a Brazilian visual artist and art historian. user.name: Berlina
user.about:
I am a hardware maker turned **front-end web developer with specialization in Javascript canvas APi**(p5.js alike). I do contact improvisation in the past 5 years and would like to discover a way to **sharpen our built-in senses**. For me, it is a way to better locate yourself in physical and increasingly overwhelming virtual world. Let's all take a deep breathe together first.  

I have made many different things/prototypes along the way of learning new skills.
I built hypnotized brainwave-interactive light installation(failed!), sound controlled flappy bird to embarrass yourself in public as an ice-breaker, digital scratch card with any amount money your want (thx to generated art), and collaborated with local artists to make Ebay(Chinese version) plug-in to hack product recommendation algorithm and  interactive Facebook wall you can read in an elevator. 

Feel free to check out my work [here](https://berlinali.github.io/work/) and talk to me in the camp.

user.name: Baaria
user.about:
I’m a virtual reality enthusiast, avid book reader of all topics, and a lifelong learner. My interests include VR/AR, storytelling, and curious thought experiments about the future of technology. My favorite question always starts with "What if..." and I often try to follow up with the answer.

I create fun and weird experiences that challenge the reality we live in with VR/AR. My approach to virtual and augmented reality is more artistically inclined, with emphasis on experience design.

I’m also an aspiring lighthouse owner, coffee drinker, and writer. I like to-do lists, cats, and people who hire me. Currently, my favorite color is green.

If you’re interested in virtual and augmented reality or collaborating to create an experience, I’d love to hear from you.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Data Driven Activism
description:
Considering the amount of fake news, alternative facts and lies coming out of the highest office in America, we as artists, designers, journalists and decent human beings should do all we can to make the fact-based truths speak louder than the falsehoods. To do this we look to the data. 

In this workshop we will cover how to find appropriate data using publicly available datasets, web scrapping and APIs, briefly cover data scrubbing and analysis, and focus on the best way to present and visualize the data. We will be covering the basics of JavaScript, jQuery, D3js, Python, Kimono, Open Refine, Datavisual, Excel and Sublime Text. This workshop is designed for anyone, but a basic understanding of the web and web languages would be helpful. Please make sure to bring a laptop for this workshop.
tag_list: data, code, data visualization, web, javascript, python, web scrapping, activism, data for good, fake news, alternative facts

leader_users.name: dannewoo
leader_users.about: For more than a decade Danne Woo has been working in New York as a graphic designer, interaction designer, and web developer for a diverse group of corporate clients. He received his MPS from NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program (ITP) where he focused on data-driven projects, musical innovation, alternative energy, and large crowd interactions. His projects have been featured on a number of blogs and magazines such as Fast Company, The Guardian, Engadget, Gizmodo, The Verge, CNet, and Make Magazine. He is founder and CEO of Datavisual (www.datavisu.al), a web-based platform for designing data-driven graphics; Assistant Professor of Interaction Design at Queens College, CUNY where he teaches classes on data visualization, creative coding and website design/development; and creative technologist at Danne Woo Design (www.dannewoo.com), which focuses on combining emerging technologies with traditional design principles. He holds the Guinness World Record for the most people playing his video game Splat at the same time on the same screen.

title: Drawing in the Terminal
description: Take a trip down memory lane to investigate the creative computing output of days gone by - the 1980s. In these early days, printing one character at a time on a monochrome screen was the only medium available. In this workshop we will learn how to use Python and external libraries to draw and animate graphics patterns in our computer console!

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

title: Build your own API
description: Everything is on the Internet, but usually not all in the same place. This workshop will be an introduction to NodeJS, a popular JavaScript environment, in order to figure out how we can grab data from a website, save it on our server, and give access to it to anyone who wants it, which will end up being our own API.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

title: Lets Make an ITP Cryptocurrency
description:
What would we do with an ITP currency? Trade it for Ron Bobs? I don't know but lets brainstorm together. 

Don't know a bitcoin from a dollar bill - No Problem! We'll cover that too.  Lets put ITP on the blockchain!  

In the course of this workshop cum skill share cum facilitated discussion we will create our own open source Ethereum token for  the ITP community.  We will build the initial  the rules of the currency and discuss use cases.  Do we want to create a token that can invest in or provide access to  ITP projects? Do we want a  DAO? Do we want a token that students  and alums can use in their own projects? 

We will look at some tokens created by companies such as Consensys, and at alternative currencies online and offline.  In thinking about these topics I have been influenced by David Graeber, Silvia Federici, Bernard Lietaer, and Charles  Eisenstein - and essentially the back catalogue of Verso. 

At Print All Over Me, the company that I run, we are implementing our loyalty/royalty program with Ethereum tokens. This is something we have been investigating for 3 years and only now feel that the technology has arrived to let us do what we want. I would love to experiment with the ITP community to make a fantastic open source cryptocurrency that we all can use in new and unexpected ways.
tag_list: itp, code, cryptocurrency, ethereum, bitcoin, commerce, debt, feminism

leader_users.name: Meredith F
leader_users.about:
I am an old school progammer humanist.  I co-founded and currently run Print All Over Me, a platform for user generated clothing.  PAOM lets me indulge all my out-there tech interests from machine learning, to twine, to cryptocurrency, in the service of making crowdsourced clothing.  I am also the co-founder and CTO of kokowa, a platform for 3D and VR user generated content.   

I attended ITP in the early aughts, and before founding PAOM, had the usual roster of creative ITPish activities while working my day job as a quant on wall street. These include founding the robotic activist group Botmatrix with fellow ITPer Cindy Jeffers, our claim to fame was working on a robotic adaptation of Hedda Gabbler - Heddatron.  I also co-founded the indie production company 13Bit Productions with fellow ITPer Paul V.  One of our decade old docs has just resurfaced as part of a retrospective at RCA in London. 

For the past few years, with Print All Over Me, I have been thinking and experimenting about different ways to engage with commerce and to transact.  So I am really excited to brainstorm and work with the other members of ITP camp and build an ITP cryptocurrency!

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Computer-Generated Stories, Jokes, Poems and Bots: No Programming Required!
description: Mainstream attention on computer-generated text focuses on its supposed ability to supplant the professional writer. In this workshop, we'll learn the truth: computer-generated text can be useful, but it's far more interesting as a creative and poetic tool, to create and thereby investigate absurd juxtapositions, poised on the brink of the infinite void of nonsense. We'll learn a tool called Tracery (created by Kate Compton), a freely available tool that makes it easy to create expressive text generators—with no prior knowledge of computer programming. (If you do know how to program, good news: there are open source libraries for incorporating Tracery grammars into your own programs.)
tag_list: text, narrative, creative writing, poetry, bots

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

user.name: Ann B
user.about: Ann Bennett is an Emmy nominated documentary filmmaker and multimedia producer. She produced the NAACP Image Award winning PBS feature documentary, "Through A Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a People" as well as the multi-platform community engagement initiative, "Digital Diaspora Family Reunion" (DDFR). Bennett's film credits include; 'Citizen King' and 'Fisk Jubilee Singers' for the PBS series "American Experience", 'Hymn for Alvin Ailey' for "Dance in America", and the award winning PBS mini-series; 'Africans in America' and 'America's War on Poverty'.  Bennett is a graduate of Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism and Harvard College.

title: Don't Tweet, Toot: Understanding Mastodon and the Federated Social Network
description: Originally released in October 2016, Mastodon—an implementation of GNU social—has recently attracted attention as a potential alternative for centralized social networks like Twitter and Facebook. With hundreds of thousands of new users in the past few months, Mastodon (and other software like it) has the potential to shift the landscape of online community. Mastodon is open source and federated: anyone can run their own instance. In this session, we'll talk about what "open source," "federated," and "instance" mean, and talk about why users are eager to use this software instead of its proprietary alternatives. In particular, we'll focus on the creative potential of a customizable social networking platform (e.g., oulipo.social, botsin.space) and take the first steps toward starting our very own Mastodon instance.

title: 3D Printed Data - Make Your Own Data Sculpture in Processing
description:
Create 3D forms from raw data using Processing and turn them into tangible objects using a 3D printer. We will cover how to work with data in Processing, how to 3D model based on data, and the process of turning sketch into an actual object. At the end of the class, you will get a ready-to-3d-print model of your own data. 

We will look at the topic of 3D printing outside the confines of 3D modeling software, enabling you to work with 3D printers in new ways.

* An example set of data will be provided at the class, but feel free to bring data which is meaningful to you.
* We will code together at the workshop so you don't need to necessarily know about Processing, but general understanding in programming language would help you to enjoy the workshop.
* You will be able to use 3D printers at ITP to print your model from the class.

title: Practical resources for machine learning for artists
description:
This tutorial will introduce practical resources, applications, and code for getting started with machine learning for creative and artistic use. It will include an overview of the materials available with [ml4a.github.io](http://ml4a.github.io), as well as a survey of helpful classes, writings, and code made by others in the field.

Most of the session will consist of tutorials for using the [Python notebooks](https://github.com/ml4a/ml4a-guides/) and [openFrameworks applications](https://github.com/ml4a/ml4a-ofx/) bundled with ml4a, including several demonstrations of Wekinator applications. It will also cover the [web-based demos](https://ml4a.github.io/demos) of ml4a, including javascript deep learning libraries of interest to web developers. It will end with a broad (but not detailed) survey of various open-source repositories for running deep learning routines to produce images and text (and maybe sound, TBD).

The tutorial is loosely a practical follow-up on the more theoretical lecture "[From principal components to puppyslugs](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2017/session/34)" on Tuesday, but attendance to that is not required to take this session.


## Tentative list of topics to cover

#### Data science tasks
 - extracting features from images, sounds, text
 - search query by feature vectors
 - t-SNE and visualization
 - training a neural network for image classification
 - transfer learning for fine-tuning a neural net to custom image classes
 - "neural net painter"

#### Real-time (mostly using openFrameworks)
 - live image classification and object detection
 - fast image search and substitution
 - train classifier for images and sounds 
 - controlling music and visual art programs with Wekinator

#### Web-side demos
 - survey of tools used in making ml4a.github.io/demos
 - convnet.js, keras.js
 - resources for computer vision in the browser

title: From principal components to puppyslugs: the mathematics of deep learning for art
description:
This lecture-based session is an accessible primer on the theory and mathematics of machine learning for artistic and creative purposes. If you have ever looked at neural creations like [Deepdream](https://research.googleblog.com/2015/06/inceptionism-going-deeper-into-neural.html), [DCGAN](https://github.com/Newmu/dcgan_code#arithmetic-on-faces), pix2pix [[1]](https://phillipi.github.io/pix2pix/)[[2]](https://affinelayer.com/pixsrv/index.html), or [AlphaGo](https://storage.googleapis.com/deepmind-media/alphago/AlphaGoNaturePaper.pdf), and wondered "how does that actually work?" then this lecture will put you on a path towards understanding it beyond the magic tricks and cliches.

This lecture assumes no advanced knowledge of math or computer science and will start from basics, relying on figures and visual aides to communicate difficult concepts wherever possible. Topics will begin with principal component analysis and probability/statistics, and progress towards neural networks, generative models, and adversarial training. Although this lecture cannot fully demystify what years of mathematical training bring, it will put you on a path towards a deeper understanding of the subject, and academic resources for pursuing the content more thoroughly will be provided for further exploration.

This lecture will be tightly coupled with a [follow-up tutorial/workshop on June 22](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2017/session/32) which will cover practical applications for machine learning for art, mostly using code and resources from [ml4a.github.io](http://ml4a.github.io). The two sessions are complimentary, but it is not necessary to attend both.

user.about: Vanessa Rosa is a Brazilian visual artist and art historian. She creates projects that mixtures public art, community activities, technological experiments and historical research, usually having painting as her main medium. Currently she has been developing a research about algorithmic images and traditional ornamentations from Portuguese, Islamic and West African cultural groups. Vanessa has worked as project coordinator for different organizations and is an illustrator and art director for Viajante do Tempo publishing company. Vanessa has a deep interest in collaboration projects and in understanding other cultures and cities. She has already proposed and participated in mural paintings, exhibitions and other projects in different countries across South and North America, Europe and this year she's heading to Africa for the first time.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Intro to Game Development with Unity
description: Unity is becoming the go-to engine for real-time interactive applications. In order to fully grasp all that it can do, this workshop will focus on its roots as a game engine. We will look at the basics of game design principles, as well as the basics of game development principles in order to develop our own game over the course of the workshop.

My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. title: p5js on the phone
description:
Take the accessibility of p5js and smash it with the versatility of smartphone sensing technology, using the cross-platform framework Apache Cordova. 

This workshop will run through the basics of getting real world data from your phone, doing something funky with it in p5, and then outputting that funkiness back into the world.

user.name: Berlina
user.about:
I am a hardware maker turned **front-end web developer with specialization in Javascript canvas APi**(p5.js alike). I do contact improvisation in the past 5 years and would like to discover a way to **sharpen our built-in senses**. For me, it is a way to better locate yourself in physical and increasingly overwhelming virtual world. Let's all take a deep breathe together first.  

I have made many different things/prototypes along the way of learning new skills.
I built hypnotized brainwave-interactive light installation(failed!), sound controlled flappy bird to embarrass yourself in public as an ice-breaker, digital scratch card with any amount money your want (thx to generated art), and collaborated with local artists to make Ebay(Chinese version) plug-in to hack product recommendation algorithm and  interactive Facebook wall you can read in an elevator. 

Feel free to check out my work [here](https://berlinali.github.io/work/) and talk to me in the camp.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

title: Unitweet: Getting real time data into unity using nodejs
description:
Feed a twitter stream right into your Unity game! Use tweet data to generate characters, enhance your world, interact with the outside, anything!

This workshop will run through the basics of getting real time data into Unity using a nodejs server. Though the example we'll use is twitter, the concepts can be ported to any open API.

user.name: Baaria

I’m a virtual reality enthusiast, avid book reader of all topics, and a lifelong learner. My interests include VR/AR, storytelling, and curious thought experiments about the future of technology. My favorite question always starts with "What if..." and I often try to follow up with the answer.

title: Storytelling is Queen
description:
A scene is the basic unit of storytelling. And for short projects, a single scene might even be the entire story, but without understanding how one is constructed, a traditional narrative will never succeed. 

Spend a fun hour learning how to construct a scene. We will talk about character motivation, build, climax and resolution. And then we’ll do an exercise where you choose a fun scenario and spin a yarn with a beginning, middle and an end.

title: Designing for Health -Human Centered Design and UX
description: Human-centered design is a creative approach to problem solving that starts with the people you are designing for and ends with new solutions that are designed to fit the end user’s needs.  We will introduce you to the concepts of human-centered design and how this approach can be used to create innovative, effective solutions for health.  We will cover user research, empathic design, constructing a user journey, personas and prototyping through an iterative process.  By the end of this session participants should have a thorough understanding of human-centered design, prototyping tools, interface evaluation techniques and designing for health tech.
tag_list: human-centered design,  rapid prototyping,  user journey, design thinking

leader_users.name: Diana Freed
leader_users.about: Diana  is a PhD student in Information Science at Cornell Tech and a Scholar in Residence at NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program (ITP). Her research spans Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), digital security and privacy, participatory design, small-data collection, and health behavior with a focus on designing, building and evaluating technologies for patients coping with behavioral health issues and chronic conditions. She has taught courses in HCI and UX/UI design in health.  She was a 2015-16 Fellow at Data and Society and is a ‘15 graduate of NYU-ITP, Columbia University and the NYU Graduate School of Arts and Science. Recent talks include; The Future of Human Computer Interaction: How Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning Will Incite Behavior Change (Social Media Week ‘17), and Designing Assistive Technologies for Activities of Daily Living (Stanford Medicine X ‘16; PervasiveHealth'16).

title: JavaScript 101 with p5.js
description: Learn the basics of programming interactivity in the browser utilizing JavaScript with p5.js (a library for creating graphic and interactive experiences). The focus will be on interacting with the canvas (for animation or drawing), and user interface elements such as buttons, and text input.

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

title: Bodies in the Browser
description:
In this hands-on workshop, participants will learn how to access to data from the Microsoft Kinect 2 Game Controller with Kinectron in a browser and share the data over the internet..
The Kinect/Kinectron has a slew of interesting capabilities that we'll try out such as:

* Skeleton tracking which allows users to do things like live puppeteer 3D avatars or interact with a webpage using their body instead of a mouse

* Depth images which allow software to determine how far a user is from the camera and can be used in combination with a regular RGB image key a user out from the background to do things like go on virtual tours.

and more!
tag_list: kinect, javascript, p5.js, programming, code, body

user.name: Berlina
user.about:
I am a hardware maker turned **front-end web developer with specialization in Javascript canvas APi**(p5.js alike). I do contact improvisation in the past 5 years and would like to discover a way to **sharpen our built-in senses**. For me, it is a way to better locate yourself in physical and increasingly overwhelming virtual world. Let's all take a deep breathe together first.  

I have made many different things/prototypes along the way of learning new skills.
I built hypnotized brainwave-interactive light installation(failed!), sound controlled flappy bird to embarrass yourself in public as an ice-breaker, digital scratch card with any amount money your want (thx to generated art), and collaborated with local artists to make Ebay(Chinese version) plug-in to hack product recommendation algorithm and  interactive Facebook wall you can read in an elevator. 

Feel free to check out my work [here](https://berlinali.github.io/work/) and talk to me in the camp.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Building/Remixing Server-side Applications using Glitch.com
description: Glitch bills itself as "the friendly community where you'll build the app of your dreams".  In this quick introduction to server-side programming, we'll use the Glitch platform (JavaScript and Node.js) to create basic web applications to serve web pages and interact with databases (put that user or sensor data somewhere and visualize it).  Along the way, we'll have some fun playing with cookies.
tag_list: server, glitch, javascript, programming, code, express, node
