leader_users.name: gabebc
leader_users.about:
Gabriel Barcia-Colombo is a mixed media artist whose work focuses on collections, memorialization and the act of leaving one's digital imprint for the next generation. His work takes the form of video sculptures, immersive performances, large scale projections and vending machines that sell human DNA. His work plays upon this modern exigency in our culture to chronicle, preserve and wax nostalgic, an idea which Barcia-Colombo renders visually by “collecting” human portraits on video.

Gabriel was recently commissioned to be the first digital artist to show work at the New Fulton Terminal Stop with the MTA Arts & Design program in New York City. His work has been featured in the Volta, Scope, and Art Mrkt art fairs as well as Grand Central Terminal and the New York Public Library. He recently received an Art and Technology grant from the Los Angeles County Museum of Art where he created "The Hereafter Institute," a company that questions the future of death rituals and memorials and their relationship to technology. 

Gabriel served as a member of the artist advisory board at the New York Foundation for the Arts, as well as the education committee member at the Museum of Art and Design. In 2012 Gabriel gave a TED talk entitled "Capturing Memories in Video Art," and in 2014 he gave another entitled "My DNA Vending Machine" and was awarded a Senior TED fellowship. In 2016 Gabe founded Bunker.nyc a pop up gallery showcasing emerging art made with technology. Gabe is a New York Foundation for the Arts grant awardee and faculty member at the Interactive Telecommunications Program at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts.

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

user.name: Vanessa Rosa
user.about: Vanessa Rosa is a Brazilian visual artist and art historian. She creates projects that mixtures public art, community activities, technological experiments and historical research, usually having painting as her main medium. Currently she has been developing a research about algorithmic images and traditional ornamentations from Portuguese, Islamic and West African cultural groups. Vanessa has worked as project coordinator for different organizations and is an illustrator and art director for Viajante do Tempo publishing company. Vanessa has a deep interest in collaboration projects and in understanding other cultures and cities. She has already proposed and participated in mural paintings, exhibitions and other projects in different countries across South and North America, Europe and this year she's heading to Africa for the first time.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

title: "Noticing" Workshop
description: This workshop teaches techniques and tools for noticing—seeing, hearing and comprehending something new. In a short series of exercises we’ll explore the observation process in an array of domains, from cognitive psychology to ethnography and drawing to data collection, with techniques for reaching that moment we all crave: when something unexpected and terrific bursts forward into consciousness. Participants should leave with their eyes opened to the inspirations and complexity that surround us, plus an individual "Noticing Plan" of observation techniques for making their next project shine.

user.name: Baaria
user.about:
I’m a virtual reality enthusiast, avid book reader of all topics, and a lifelong learner. My interests include VR/AR, storytelling, and curious thought experiments about the future of technology. My favorite question always starts with "What if..." and I often try to follow up with the answer.

I create fun and weird experiences that challenge the reality we live in with VR/AR. My approach to virtual and augmented reality is more artistically inclined, with emphasis on experience design.

I’m also an aspiring lighthouse owner, coffee drinker, and writer. I like to-do lists, cats, and people who hire me. Currently, my favorite color is green.

If you’re interested in virtual and augmented reality or collaborating to create an experience, I’d love to hear from you.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

user.name: Vanessa Rosa

Currently she has been developing a research about algorithmic images and traditional ornamentations from Portuguese, Islamic and West African cultural groups. Vanessa has worked as project coordinator for different organizations and is an illustrator and art director for Viajante do Tempo publishing company. Vanessa has a deep interest in collaboration projects and in understanding other cultures and cities. She has already proposed and participated in mural paintings, exhibitions and other projects in different countries across South and North America, Europe and this year she's heading to Africa for the first time.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Body Based Sculpture Workshop: Session 1
description: This is a sculpture workshop dedicated to the creation of hand crafted forms which may be worn on the body. This is a great opportunity to prototype ideas with soft materials. Participants with combine textile and mixed media components to create fantastic wearable pieces using basic skills in small garment construction, felting techniques, simple sewing and wire armature building. We will have polymer clay, basic jewellery making supplies, and access to sewing machines, so if you have any cool ideas there is lots of wiggle room to think big and small in wearable art! We are planning to hold 2 meetings for the Body Based Sculpture Workshop. By the end of the workshop, we will have a quick photo session featuring role-play with the artwork if you so desire!

leader_users.name: Valerie Carew
leader_users.about: I am a multi-disciplinary artist with a focus in textile media, sculpture/ installation and performance. I am a graduate from the Interdisciplinary Master’s in Art, Media and Design Program at OCAD University. In my art practice, I seek out local species in the natural world which characterize own reclusive tendencies, and apply these attributes to personal contexts related to domesticity and gendered norms. I explore these comparisons in dwelling through wearable art, role-play, and field research.

title: Soft Robotics and Bioinspiration
description:
Roboticists frequently find inspiration from the incredible evolved forms of nature, and translate them into fresh thinking and solutions. This workshop invites you to explore this fast-growing domain where biology and robotics collide.

This 4hr workshop will take participants from any skill level through what it takes to be a researcher on the forefront of soft robotics. Workshop activities include:

* Learning from actual robot designers about the state of the art of soft robotics
* Building your own inflatable robotic actuators
* Mixing and matching different fields to come up with bioinspired designs
* Learning tools to go from idea to prototype to product faster than ever before
tag_list: bioinspiration, soft robotics, wearables, interdisciplinary, biomimetics, engineering, design, hands-on, hands on, pneumatic, inflatables

I've also contracted on NASA-funded space suit research, built Broadway costumes, made and dressed puppets, spoke at the White House representing a hacker space, and been a Zero-G bridesmaid. All improbable, but factual.

title: The Rise of Zombie Motors
description:
Motors are in tons of consumer electronics and serve a range of functions, from the vibration motors common in mobile devices, to the DC motors in RC cars and drones, to the super precise stepper motors in 3-D printers. 

In this session, we will go over various methods for controlling different motors, from the simplest button-based circuit, to more complex motor-control circuits and microcontroller based methods, you can choose the level of complexity that suits your motor-based idea. 

Bring along your old electronics and we can pull the motors out of them. For example, old Walkmen or CD players, the fans within PC computer towers, dead mechanical children’s toys such as the dreaded Furby or even an old electric toothbrush. Also bring an Arduino or the microcontroller of your choice if possible.

title: Video Editing: Timing, Montage and Collage
description:
Editing video documentation of your work is an art in and of itself. From the plethora of video mash-ups of news footage and current events on YouTube, to the montage-based video works of artists Christian Marclay and Natalie Bookchin, it is clear that the meaning of the video lies not just in what you film, but how you cut it together.

In this session we will go over the basics of editing for meaning in Adobe Premiere Pro. Some video clips will be provided for practice, but feel free to also bring your own, be they family home videos, your old collection of Buffy DVDS, or clips ripped from YouTube, this will be a fun and hands-on learning session. Download a free trial of Adobe Premiere Pro prior to attending.

title: Speculative Design and Science Fiction: The blurry boundaries between fact, fiction, and tech design.
description:
Speculative design is an alternative design process that has gained momentum in the last decade as a tool for approaching difficult and abstract problems pertaining to humankind’s future and its relationship to technology and sustainability (Bleecker, 2009; Candy, 2010; Dunne and Raby, 2013). While design fields such as product design and industrial design tend to address immediate problems with literal, design-based solutions, speculative design looks further into the future and produces design propositions that are not beholden to literal questions of marketability or scalability, allowing for the production of imaginative, provocative and critical ideas.

This one-hour lecture will give a brief overview of contemporary speculative design, as well as the many instances of overlaps between speculative design, science fiction, and consumer tech development.

title: Design Systems: How to solve problems in complex multi-system spaces like the IOT, interactive experiences, and multi-platform apps
description:
This workshop will take you through simple methods for getting a handle on complex design challenges that step between disciplines. Building a tremendous experience on everything from IOT devices to theme park rides hinges on the ability to understand and control aspects that affect the user experience even if the problem falls outside of your own domain expertise.

In this workshop, we will practice tools and techniques for mapping, evaluating, and understand designs for complex systems. The workshop features participatory exercises, sketching lessons, and improv games.

title: Launch Weekend: Intro to Physical Computing
description:
An introductory session about physical computing! Come learn about using Arduino with simple sensors, buttons, LEDs, and motors!

The format of this session will be a short lecture (30 mins) followed by a hands-on group activity / workshop (60-90 mins). 

__Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels__, _although the emphasis will be on fundamental concepts._

Once we go over the basics of working with a microcontroller, you'll have a few different circuits to build on your own and code. At the end, everyone will pair up and (hopefully) complete a giant Rube Goldberg machine, connecting all the devices sequentially! 

While some supplies will be available to use, campers are encouraged to bring their own Arduino, breadboard, USB cable, and laptop with the [Arduino IDE installed from arduino.cc](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software). If you have a sensor or actuator you want to try out, bring that along too!

Link to google drive resources - [https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B5HFDPTSNkLxZ2FRRzY2VFI0Y2c](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B5HFDPTSNkLxZ2FRRzY2VFI0Y2c)
tag_list: launchweekend, physicalcomputing, arduino, beginner, fundamentals, fun
counselor_comments:
Great start to Camp! Everyone seemed enthused to try out everything, and it was great to see people get excited over their first blinking LED. Scott was good with explaining, and the Fritzing schematics were excellent. Had all the resources available and quickly addressed a minor code issue.

However some room for improvement. Definitely will need more supplies available or assign teams, or if the day before some 'starter' kit for people to borrow (and maybe some suggestion for people to bring their own if they have them).

One of his Fritzing schematics wasn't laid out correctly (he swapped the power and ground colors), causing many new people to mix up  the layout of breadboard causing some issues. (I understand that unlike the code, this would have been harder to fix on the fly but I am just reporting on hat I as most called on to assist.)

He also had the code set to move the servo once to encourage them to figure out how to get it to work on more than one press to explore the code-- I think next time if he could let the counselors assisting know so when we are flagged, we can let them know.

Although we didn't get to the Rube Goldberg device (maybe  another session?), campers seemed happy to just experiment with the projects presented.

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

user.name: Pablo Ricaurte Llorente
user.about:
Hi, my name is Pablo, I´m from Colombia and my background is a degree in industrial design in Bogotá, DC.
I work creating interactive light installations from waste material in party´s, concerts, nightclubs and all kind of events and venues for the entertainments industry. I have designed booths for many dj´s that have come to my city. This is my first time at the ITP, it looks amazing! At the moment I´m working with LED fixtures built from "trash" and mix the system through the sound so you can feel immersed in a synesthetic environment, like an audio/visual system that goes with the frequencies of the audio. The waste material fixtures are made out of up-cycling products and converting them into LED fixtures in to screens, where the users can play with tablets, displays, cameras and other kind of sensors. I´d love to teach everybody how to solder, plug and program LEDs, create visual content that flows with the music and how to build fixtures out of waste material, to create new products.

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

title: Launch Weekend: Intro to 3D Modeling
description:
An introductory session about 3D modeling for design, fabrication, and VR.

We'll be working with a trial version of Rhinoceros, but many of these concepts translate into other modeling platforms, such as SketchUp, Maya, Cinema4D, Blender.

Please download a 90 day trial of Rhino here:
[http://www.rhino3d.com/download](http://www.rhino3d.com/download)

We'll go over the basics of 3D modeling, common considerations for VR and game engines, and interfacing with other applications and outputting information for Laser Cutters, Mills, and 3D printers.

If you're interested in Game Engines and VR, please download and install Unity Engine:
[https://unity3d.com/get-unity/download](https://unity3d.com/get-unity/download)

If you're interested in 3D printing on the MakerBots at ITP, please download and install Makerbot Print:
[https://www.makerbot.com/download-print/](https://www.makerbot.com/download-print/)

The format of this session will be a short lecture (30 mins) followed by a hands-on workshop (60-90 mins).

Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels, although the emphasis will be on fundamental concepts.

Please download this file:
[Into to Rhino Work File](https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B0gTX-HwGr4XUmhJVkFJNGk2eGs)

Link to a previously recorded session covering many of the same tools:
[Recording of Session](https://vimeo.com/106006433)
counselor_comments:
Really well organized session.  The pace was perfect for intro into a program like Rhino.  David, made the point to note that the tools shown in the session were tools that were common in most modeling softwares, and identified other modeling programs that could accomplish similar things that would be covered in the session. David made a downloadable file with precomposed, clear examples with labels for the commands illustrated.  This was perfect and got things started will little to no confusion.    He began by giving clear instructions into Rhino's user interface before moving into examples.  The structure started with primitive geometries and moved gradually into more complex geometry manipulations.

In the end, David showed how to export the mesh geometries for 3D printing (in Cura) and game assets (in Unity).   This was very short but sparked peoples intrigue into the applications of computer modeling.

For the next round, I would suggest having campers download the files a head of time and 3-button mice to be provided.  There was about 15 minutes of people downloading before the session could start and it was difficult for those who did not have a mouse to navigate the software's interface and follow along.  I would also suggest a larger portion of time for campers to explore the software program and investigate it's capabilities on their own.  This would encourage mistakes to happen, problems to be solved,  and more questions to be asked.  

Overall, a very thorough and well taught session.

leader_users.name: David Tracy
leader_users.about:
I'm a creative technologist and ITP alum. 

I currently spend my days at an architecture firm called Rockwell Group in a studio called the LAB. We design and build software for permanent interactive spatial media installations. I spend a lot of time writing C# and building prototypes in Unity. I'm currently working on a VR software platform for a hotel brand, a series of kinetic installations in the Bahamas, and a giant interactive elevator tower in New Dehli.

Before switching into technology, I was a designer at a large architecture firm in Chicago working on architecture, interior renovations, and furniture. It was here I leveled up my 3D skill set and learned to love working with parametric design tools.

I help teach students (and troubleshoot) how to use Avid, Premiere Pro, DaVinci Resolve, etc.
I also color grade on the side - currently waiting on a full length feature doc about Manhattan Plaza for performing artists!

Though it's a great job, there's no room for growth/ promotion, and little more I can learn.
Since I've always had an intense interest in all things computer/ gaming/ coding/ Arduinos/ etc, I'm taking ITP Camp for an intro into the field and, hopefully, a new career direction.

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

user.name: Vanessa Rosa
user.about: Vanessa Rosa is a Brazilian visual artist and art historian. She creates projects that mixtures public art, community activities, technological experiments and historical research, usually having painting as her main medium. Currently she has been developing a research about algorithmic images and traditional ornamentations from Portuguese, Islamic and West African cultural groups. Vanessa has worked as project coordinator for different organizations and is an illustrator and art director for Viajante do Tempo publishing company. Vanessa has a deep interest in collaboration projects and in understanding other cultures and cities. She has already proposed and participated in mural paintings, exhibitions and other projects in different countries across South and North America, Europe and this year she's heading to Africa for the first time.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Launch Weekend: Intro to Computation with p5.js
description:
Introduction to Creative Coding with p5.js

In this workshop you will learn the fundamentals of programming while creating visual compositions. In learning about variables, conditionals, and loops, you will use lines and shapes to create drawings and animations.

The format of this session will be a short lecture followed by a hands-on group activity.

Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels, although the emphasis of this workshop will be on fundamental programming concepts.

Class Notes: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NdSvzGMktnlUT7s4wA9PCWsR_BtGPx8ASBddb9mvH3k/edit?usp=sharing
tag_list: launchweekend, code, p5, computation, web, javascript, programming, beginner
counselor_comments:
Cassie did a very good introductory workshop, and overall, there is a very active vibe amongst the attendants. 
The session began with a general intro to the p5.js library, how it can be used, and a quick look at some very inspiring art piece made with generative code. The coding part of the workshop is well-paced. The first half of the session introduced colors(grey, RGB), shapes and stroke, and how those elements are controlled by parameters. There is a short break for trouble-shooting, though most of the attendants were well on track and were already looking up the p5 website for more codes.
The second half of the session, which covers the "draw()" function, loops, mouse location, "random()" and "map()" functions and "if" statement, was slightly faster. In particular, when declaring "var position" and "var speed" as global variables, there were a few attendants that missed the part and had trouble running the code.
People in general definitely had a lot fun drawing with p5 :)

title: Launch Weekend: Video & Sound
description:
An introduction to photo + video + sound for documentation

The format of this session will be a short lecture followed by a hands-on group activity.

Open to Campers of all backgrounds and skill levels, although the emphasis of this workshop will to introduce fundamental concepts and skills including shooting with a 5D DSLR camera, recording audio with the Zoom recorder and best practices for documentation of your camp projects.

Taught by Gabe BC
counselor_comments: Great intro the video and sound, for the first hour Gabe gave a lecture of many good example projects and overview of the basics. After the campers went in groups with a DSLR or 360 camera and a Zoom recorder to test out the equipment for 45 minutes.

leader_users.name: gabebc
leader_users.about:
Gabriel Barcia-Colombo is a mixed media artist whose work focuses on collections, memorialization and the act of leaving one's digital imprint for the next generation. His work takes the form of video sculptures, immersive performances, large scale projections and vending machines that sell human DNA. His work plays upon this modern exigency in our culture to chronicle, preserve and wax nostalgic, an idea which Barcia-Colombo renders visually by “collecting” human portraits on video.

Gabriel was recently commissioned to be the first digital artist to show work at the New Fulton Terminal Stop with the MTA Arts & Design program in New York City. His work has been featured in the Volta, Scope, and Art Mrkt art fairs as well as Grand Central Terminal and the New York Public Library. He recently received an Art and Technology grant from the Los Angeles County Museum of Art where he created "The Hereafter Institute," a company that questions the future of death rituals and memorials and their relationship to technology. 

Gabriel served as a member of the artist advisory board at the New York Foundation for the Arts, as well as the education committee member at the Museum of Art and Design. In 2012 Gabriel gave a TED talk entitled "Capturing Memories in Video Art," and in 2014 he gave another entitled "My DNA Vending Machine" and was awarded a Senior TED fellowship. In 2016 Gabe founded Bunker.nyc a pop up gallery showcasing emerging art made with technology. Gabe is a New York Foundation for the Arts grant awardee and faculty member at the Interactive Telecommunications Program at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts.

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

user.name: Berlina
user.about:
I am a hardware maker turned **front-end web developer with specialization in Javascript canvas APi**(p5.js alike). I do contact improvisation in the past 5 years and would like to discover a way to **sharpen our built-in senses**. For me, it is a way to better locate yourself in physical and increasingly overwhelming virtual world. Let's all take a deep breathe together first.  

I have made many different things/prototypes along the way of learning new skills.
I built hypnotized brainwave-interactive light installation(failed!), sound controlled flappy bird to embarrass yourself in public as an ice-breaker, digital scratch card with any amount money your want (thx to generated art), and collaborated with local artists to make Ebay(Chinese version) plug-in to hack product recommendation algorithm and  interactive Facebook wall you can read in an elevator. 

Feel free to check out my work [here](https://berlinali.github.io/work/) and talk to me in the camp.

title: Diagramming Through Our Uncertainty
description:
Uncertainty is one of the only certainties of working with emerging technology. Examinations of approaches to this paradox left me captivated by diagrams for pathways through innovation. These diagrams span from Russian TRIZ in the 1940s, OODA loop, joke diagrams of every known Agile cultural practice, Stanford d.school process, and iterations for simulation approaches in soft robotics development.

This talk surveys diagrams of processes across time, domains, and goals. It serves as a starting point about whether these models can inspire your own practices or, if not, maybe you'll want to roll your own.

title: Making Things Talk, new edition! More Talking! Now with JavaScript!
description: If you’re interested in connecting physical devices to networks, you’ll probably find Making Things Talk to be a useful book. I just finished a third edition of it, adding new programming tools like p5.js and node.js,  and updating the microcontrollers used to include Raspberry Pi, newer Arduino boards like the Arduino 101 and MKR1000, and the ESP8266 microcontroller. In this talk, I’ll give an overview of the book, and highlight sections that might be useful to campers working on connected hardware.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Programming Devices that Talk to the Web
description: Connecting devices to networks can be a confusing subject, because there are  many approaches. Even if you’re using the Arduino IDE, learning the software can be a challenge because different developers roll their own libraries, and not always in a style that’s friendly to beginners.  In this workshop, I’ll show you how to use Arduino MKR1000 and ESP8266 simply and effectively, using libraries that were designed in the spirit of the Arduino API.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

I’m a virtual reality enthusiast, avid book reader of all topics, and a lifelong learner. My interests include VR/AR, storytelling, and curious thought experiments about the future of technology. My favorite question always starts with "What if..." and I often try to follow up with the answer.

If you’re interested in virtual and augmented reality or collaborating to create an experience, I’d love to hear from you.

title: Really Bright Lights: DMX Lighting with node.js
description:
So maybe you've controlled some LEDs to light things up, but what about brighter lights?  

DMX-512 is an international standard for control of stage and live entertainment lighting. In this session, you’ll learn to control stage lighting using node.js. After that, you can use any of the stage lights we have on the floor at ITP.

title: Home Lights: Programming Philips Hue with JavaScript

title: Artist Talk: Body Sculptures and Role-Play
description: Interdisciplinary artist Valerie Carew will present her body based, performative sculptural work. Carew will discuss body sculptures as an evocative way to extend body language and communicate ideas by using the human form as a substrate for art making. Part of her presentation will show her MFA thesis work from OCAD University, which features biomimetic role-play of species in southern Ontario farmland ecosystems.
tag_list: biomimicry, role-play, sculpture, wearables, performance art, interdisciplinary

leader_users.name: Valerie Carew
leader_users.about: I am a multi-disciplinary artist with a focus in textile media, sculpture/ installation and performance. I am a graduate from the Interdisciplinary Master’s in Art, Media and Design Program at OCAD University. In my art practice, I seek out local species in the natural world which characterize own reclusive tendencies, and apply these attributes to personal contexts related to domesticity and gendered norms. I explore these comparisons in dwelling through wearable art, role-play, and field research.

title: Get Started With Neural Networks & Machine Learning!
description:
In this beginners workshop we will go over a variety of open-source machine learning projects, explore and discuss how we can use them for our art/design/etc. endeavours - and train a small neural network.  

To get you started quickly, we skip most of the maths & theory and dive right into this fascinating world in two parts:

### Discovery
We have a quick look at existing neural networks and machine learning implementations that can serve as *artistic tools* for  
• sound generation  
• text/handwriting generation  
• image recognition/generation  
• interaction  
and talk about *basic workflows*.

### Hands-on Fun
We then train and run *interactive sound/visual experiments* with [wekinator](http://www.wekinator.org/) open source software. 

Highly recommended as a great follow up on this topic:
[Gene Kogan's sessions later in June](https://itp.nyu.edu/camp2017/session/34)


###Get Ready
Please download the [wekinator-software](http://www.wekinator.org/downloads/) and the [quick-start-pack](http://www.wekinator.org/examples/) prior to the session.
tag_list: Neural Networks, Machine Learning, Art, Interaction Design, Intro

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: MEET THE ULTIMAKER 3: Ultimaker Basic Use & Safety Class
description:
Last October, Ultimaker launched the Ultimaker 3, our latest accessible, hackable professional desktop 3D printer. The Ultimaker 3 offers accurate, consistent results, and allows you to produce highly complex 3D prints with a new approach to dual extrusion with our dissolvable PVA support material.

The response among product designers, artists, makers, engineers, educators, students and industrial/manufacturing communities has been overwhelmingly positive, with machines finding homes all over the place, even in fields we never imagined.

The Ultimaker Community Team wants to introduce you to the newest member of our family, and show you how to use the Ultimaker 3. With this new 3D printer comes a lot more than what you would expect at first sight, including new features and tweaks to our Cura Software, an iOS App, and a line-up of easy to use engineering materials that can help you accomplish more with your printing.

In this session, you’ll learn everything you need to print on an Ultimaker 3D printer, including:
- Calibration and operation
- Selecting materials suitable to your project
- Troubleshooting common problems
- Design suggestions to set your jobs up for success
- ITPcamp Ultimaker printer shop policies.
- How to complete training to gain permission for testing engineering materials during this camp year.
- Access to the best resources to quickly level up with intermediate and advanced usage topics

leader_users.name: Ultimaker Community Team
leader_users.about:
From the very beginning, our mission has been to empower and inspire people around the world by developing open source 3D printers and tools. And thanks to our talented team, that’s just what we’re doing.

Matthew Griffin and Lizabeth Arum are members of the Ultimaker Community Team.

__Matthew Griffin__ is the Director of Community for Ultimaker North America. He is currently finishing a lecture series on 3D Printing Hardware for Coursera, a book on design for 3D printing, and is a writer, teacher, and consultant covering topics such as 3D Printing, electronics hobbyists, and more. He has taught Digital Fabrication at Maryland Institute College of Arts (MICA). He has been a regular contributor to MAKE Magazine including the annual Make: Ultimate Guide to 3DP series. Previously, he was community manager at Makerbot Industries and Director of Community & Support at Adafruit.

__Lizabeth Arum__, an artist, tinkerer and educator, is Ultimaker’s North American Education Community Strategist. She manages Ultimaker's North American Pioneer Program and works with educators to help them incorporate 3D printing into their curricula.  She received a BFA from Cooper Union, an MPS from NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program (ITP), was Makerbot’s Education Coordinator from 2011 to 2013 and taught Physical Computing and computer science to middle and high school students from 2002-2016.[Ultimaker.com/education]( http://ultimaker.com/education)

user.name: Nicole B
user.about:
Currently working on the 10th Fl - NYU Tisch Film & TV Grads & Upper class-men.

I help teach students (and troubleshoot) how to use Avid, Premiere Pro, DaVinci Resolve, etc.
I also color grade on the side - currently waiting on a full length feature doc about Manhattan Plaza for performing artists!

Though it's a great job, there's no room for growth/ promotion, and little more I can learn.
Since I've always had an intense interest in all things computer/ gaming/ coding/ Arduinos/ etc, I'm taking ITP Camp for an intro into the field and, hopefully, a new career direction.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: CURA Software - Pro Tips, Tricks, and What's Happening Under the Hood
description:
Open source Cura software [cura software](https://ultimaker.com/en/products/cura-software), actively developed by the Ultimaker software team in collaboration with the community, continues to be the widest adopted 3D printer control software across the desktop 3D printing landscape. Ultimaker uses it, top competitors to Ultimaker use it, and machine builders use it develop, tweak, and test brand new printers and other fabrication robots.

While novices love how easy Cura makes it to prepare your model for 3D printing, there is considerable power under the hood for expert users. Over 200 settings to adjust to your needs, and a newly updated structure for managing profiles for machines, toolheads, platforms, materials, and models, as well as some great new resources for developing your own Cura plugins.

In this session, we will explore basic and advance use of the software, including going under the hood to better understand how the parts of Cura fit together, and how you can draw on these resources to better understand your CuraEngine slicing options, new features related to printer/job management, and other unexpected purposes you can put to Cura. Attendees will master a handful of the most critical settings and options, and become familiar with the best resources to explore these many complex, interdependent options in greater detail for futher study.

Because Cura is open source, our community (including Ultimaker competitors!) helps to enrich it even more with each new version launched. Session will include details how you can participate in the development of this software via Github, Ultimaker Community, your own hosted profiles and solutions, creating your own plugins, and more.

title: The 3D Stuff Your Dreams Are Made Of: Engineering Grade Materials for FFF/FDM Desktop 3D Printers
description:
There are many materials you can process through a desktop 3D printer these days, and a number of 3D printer models engineered specifically to better handle a broad range of material types, properties, and temperatures ranges. Whether you are looking to 3D print a prototype, a part for fit and function testing or an end-use part, a variety of materials are available to you, especially if you are working with an open-source 3D printer.

For all of the opportunities desktop 3D printers offer artists, innovators, designers, and engineers, the ITPcamp community spends far too little time deeply exploring the nature of the eccentric polymers that are themselves “the 3D stuff your dreams are made of.” This session draws from recent filament manufacturer insights into how thermoplastics, thermoelastomers, composite materials, etc, are produced, strategies for how to make better use of standards as well as “exotics,” and why 2017 will be the most exciting year for desktop 3D printing materials to date.

This session aims to address key topics for materials that can be applied to all FFF-style desktop 3D printers -- and help you apply this knowledge with the use of the Ultimaker desktop 3D printers and materials available for your use at ITPCamp this June.

A few of the topics we aim to cover:
- What materials work best for which application? 
- Have you ever wondered what the advantages and disadvantages are of using Nylon versus PLA?
- What can you do to prevent ABS from warping? 
- When to use PC as a print material?
- What adhesion methods work best for each material and why?
- What post processing options are available?
- How can we best leverage the range of dissolveable, breakaway, and otherwise sacrificial materials to print complex parts more easily on a dual extruder machine?

We will discuss technical specifications, tips and tricks, and the best material for a variety of applications, and also look into how to take advantage of open filament systems to print with materials such as Carbon Fiber.

title: Sonic Spectrum Lab: Interactive Visuals
description:
Learn how to use coding in a creative way that interacts with your body's movements or sounds.

The course will be broken up into 3 sections: I. The possibilities of interactive visuals - will show a few projects that use coding to create interactive experiences. II. A quick intro to softwares that are great for writing code and manipulating visuals: p5.js, processing and Isadora. III. A class exhibition on what we all have created.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. title: The Components of Interactive Application Design
description:
Have an idea for an app or product, but don't know where to start?  We will dive into the known unknowns of digital production  Databases, interfaces, APIs, front-end, back-end, design, frameworks, platforms, user experience design.... what are all these things and how do they fit together to actually make something useful and interesting?

This session is meant to teach you the parts that make up a contemporary application.  And we will review the architecture of how these parts fit together, the roles of people involved in such projects, and recommendations on future sessions to attend to learn the nuts and bolts necessary to bring your idea to fruition.

This session will be entirely lecture, conversation, and drawing on an artificial chalk board.  No coding or actual engineering will take place, so breathe easy.

title: Laser Cut Stencils
description:
Learn how to use a laser cutter to paint anything you want with the stencil technique! From Street Art and art installations projects to customizing t-shirts and much more, laser cut stencils offer beautiful and complex designs with little effort.

30 min 
*Talk about art projects that use complicated stencils or laser cut as their main technique. Plus, other possibilities of DIY projects with stencils..
10 min - 
*How to prepare a file for the laser cutter - accepted formats, softwares that can be used (open source and adobe softwares)
*Basic explanations about the laser - materials, types of machines, different prices
60 min - 
* Each student will make an exercise of how to transform a picture into a stencil, several stencils and files examples will be presented. They will follow the transformation of a photograph into a stencil file and then do the same with a similar picture of their choice.
50 min - 
* The pieces developed by the students will be cut. They have to be small pieces from 2 to 4 min cutting time (depends on how many lasers the space offers)
* Basic explanation of how to use the laser in the process: turning on the smoke exhaust and the laser, downloading files to the laser, speed/intensity according to choosen materials, putting the material on the laser board, verifying laser calibration, origin point, cutting area box, firing the laserrrr.
* Basic explanation of how to use a spray can for a stencil and other possible painting techniques. In this moment it's necessary to go to an open space or a painting booth.
tag_list: laser cut, stencil, street art, art

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

title: Creating Intelligent Architecture by Augmenting it with Data
description:
Can architecture become more intelligent? Can we be more engaged in the spaces we inhabit? Are there new ways in which we can experience architecture? Can we make architecture come alive? How can architecture have an ever changing quality based on its environment? Can it change your reality? 

William Gibson proclaimed that one of the things our grandchildren will find quaintest about us is that we distinguished the digital from the real.

How might visualising data transform spaces into places by connecting people more deeply to their surroundings.

We'll be thinking and implementing ways on how to transform architectural spaces using live data. 

We're not talking about basic projection mapping here. But rather how we can augment structures and data to transform public spaces.

Coding in Javascript or processing, and knowledge of projection mapping would be an advantage. Think of data you'd like to visualize. If anyone knows of any buildings where we could project, please let me know.

Luckily NY has a wealth of open data:
[https://data.ny.gov/](https://data.ny.gov/)
[https://opendata.cityofnewyork.us/how-to/#apidocumentation](https://opendata.cityofnewyork.us/how-to/#apidocumentation)

Maptastic is an awesome and simple JS library for projection mapping
[https://github.com/mhellar/maptasticjs](https://github.com/mhellar/maptasticjs)
tag_list: data, creative coding, javascript, projection mapping, architecture

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

title: Advanced generative coding in Javascript
description:
A workshop and contemplation on how to turn your visuals from "sketches" into evolving generative pieces. Too often our visuals are one-dimensional eye-candy. We'll explore ways we can make our generative sound reactive more fluid and evolving. 

Prior knowledge of making visuals in Javascript or p5.js would be a major advantage. As would having attended my "how to make a VJ engine in Javascript" and "Javascript sound and motion reactive systems" be extremely helpful. 

Upfront, I must say I do not have the answers. I'll show how I built my VJ engine, and some of the problems and solutions, and we'll then collaboratively explore new ways to evolve our art.

title: Javascript Audio Visual Art - creating sound and motion reactive systems
description:
How to use particle systems to create audio visual graphics in the browser. 
Using pure Javascript I'll' show you how to create sound reactive and motion reactive artworks.
Previous Javascript knowledge would be an advantage. 


=====================================

Workshop Requirements:
 
1. Laptop with webcam and working microphone input
 
2. Chrome Browser
You’ll need to have the latest version of Chrome installed [https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/index.html](https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/index.html)

(but really, Atom is great)

[https://atom.io/packages/atom-live-server](https://atom.io/packages/atom-live-server)
For maximum happiness make sure your default browser is Chrome.
 
5. A basic understanding of the web and HTML:
Again, not really needed, but will go a long way in helping you get more out of the course and make better art.

My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

user.name: Kirill S

I'm a Soviet- Born multimedia artist living in Brooklyn. Seven years ago, after realizing that my personal beliefs had never concurred with the majority of my native country, I moved to America in search of the expression of my feelings, thoughts, and ideas, especially in art and design.

I love computers and Internet. I spend good portion of my day in front of the screen, designing, researching and sometimes just mucking about. Music, hanging out with my friends, snowboarding, soccer, drinking and eating, watching movies, and traveling pretty much sums up the remainder of my time.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.
