title: How to make a VJ engine in Javascript
description:
How to build a Javascript visual engine in the browser for VJing and installations. 
File management can get complicated. You've made tonnes of sketches. Now how do you pull it all together? 

I'll take you through my thought process and practicalities of building a browser based VJ engine - based off my RBVJ engine, which recently won the W3C web audio challenge.

Knowledge in JS and HTML would be a serious advantage. 
Attending one of my other Javascript workshops will help a lot.

title: Arduino To Go: Digital and Analog Read/Write
description:
If you missed the introductory physical computing/Arduino session, or want a refresher on the basics behind digital and analog sensing this is the session for you! Jody Culkin and Eric Hagan will be conducting a short lecture and hands-on workshop to make you feel more comfortable with small scale electronics and brainstorming personal projects.

What to bring:

* Laptop (with Arduino IDE installed if possible)
* Arduino Uno
* USB cable
* Breadboard

Download Arduino IDE [here](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software). Download the IDE for Mac, Windows or Linux, don't use the online editor.

**Where to get an Arduino Uno, a breadboard and a USB A-B cable?**

**Online vendors:**

[Adafruit](https://www.adafruit.com/) is in Brooklyn, short turn-around time for shipping

[Sparkfun](https://www.sparkfun.com/) Electronics

[Maker Shed](http://www.makershed.com/) online store

[Arduino site](https://store.arduino.cc/usa/) You can buy an Uno directly from the Arduino site.

**Local stores:**

[Tinkersphere](http://tinkersphere.com/) is located at 304 East 5th Street, within walking distance. They have a pretty extensive stock available at the store. 

[Microcenter](http://www.microcenter.com/) is located in Sunset Park, and has a number of components (including inexpensive off-brand Arduino Unos).

Other parts will be available to borrow for the purpose of the session. 

We will be referencing both our in-process book project [Arduino To Go](http://arduinotogo.com/), as well as Jody's [breadboard](http://www.jodyculkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/breadboard.pdf) and [Arduino](http://www.jodyculkin.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/arduino-comic-2014.pdf) comics.

And a very useful link: [Arduino Software Reference](https://www.arduino.cc/en/Reference/HomePage)

title: Arduino to Go: Servo Motors and Project development
description:
This is a follow up to the first Arduino To Go Session, but you don't need to attend the first session to come to this one. 

We will cover the basics of using servo motors with the Arduino, including how to synchronize servo motion utilizing more advanced Arduino programming (custom functions and mapped sensor values). We will also use this session to build motion-based small scale kinetic projects and help with developing the projects you want to build during camp. If you have a servo motor bring it, but we will have some motors to borrow. We will provide a variety of materials to help make your session projects happen. 

What to bring: Laptop (with Arduino IDE installed if possible), Arduino Uno, USB cord, Breadboard

Other parts will be available to borrow for the purpose of the session.

We will be referencing both their in process book project Arduino To Go, as well as Jody's breadboard and Arduino comics.

title: Intro to Programming Languages 101, for Future Presidents
description:
aka the "Language" in "Programming Languages"

The goal: Get better at the one programming language you care about most (and this might be different for everyone). Similar to how studying a foreign language in high school gave you a different context with which to evaluate your native tongue, we'll aim to expose you to other programming languages with the hopes that you'll understand all of them better.

In other words, learn to be more effective in **ANY** programming language! Together we'll compare language concepts between two or three different programming languages. In doing so, we'll learn about what composes a programming language. We'll touch upon:

0. History
1. Syntax
2. Semantics
3. Idioms
4. Libraries
5. Tools
6. Community

Regardless of what language you're looking to master, this session aims to take a step back to see how other languages work. We'll primarily dive into a language you're likely not familiar with: Ruby! For the most part, we'll compare with Javascript, but I promise to also sprinkle in some examples from other languages along the way.

It's a short session, so we'll keep the examples simple with the option to dive into more complexity at the end depending on interest.

Prerequisites:

- Aimed at the intermediate-level programmer with some experience in one or two programming languages
- But also valuable to any novice with some programming experience and an interest for more!

Tools:

- Laptop
- We'll use a few different tools to test our code in: terminal and a couple browser interpreters. Everything is built in so you won't need extra software.

leader_users.name: Anthony B
leader_users.about:
I’m particularly excited to work on projects that explore some of our unconscious biases and leverage technology to help us step outside our own bubbles. Slightly outside my professional expertise, I’d also like to explore leading sessions exploring mental health, abstaining from technology, whimsical hacks, and falling in love with open source.

I’m a senior software engineer at Dia&Co, a startup revolutionizing the often overlooked plus-size fashion industry. title: Saturday Sessions: playing with touchscreens
description:
Saturday Sessions are a chance for campers to not only learn but to apply their skills and make something, with opportunities to work individually or collaboratively. Think of them like hackathons but a lot more chill. There will be an introduction to the tools and concepts for those unfamiliar at the beginning of the sessions, and counselors to assist everyone throughout. 

For the first session we will look at p5.js and its capabilities with touch screens. You can make a drawing app, a game, procedural art that responds to a touch input, whatever comes to your mind. Projects have the opportunity to be featured on the screens in the hallway which take up to 8 touch inputs.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

title: Election Hacking, A Practical Guide
description:
In this session, we will look at the known techniques for influencing an election, across all media, technologies, and other channels of influence.  And we will collectively draft case studies and a 'how-to' guide for anyone looking to do the same or defend against it in future.

The output of this session will be a practical guide to hacking elections, along the lines of the 1968 classic book "Coup d'Etat" (see http://amzn.to/2rwgNOb).

If it goes well, we will then self-publish and make available for download on Amazon.com, and provide it as a resources for future generations of policy-makers and politicians.

Interested parties of any political affiliation (or none at all) are welcome!

title: Hands-on Genome Editing with CRISPR
description: CRISPR has been described as a word processor for genomes. Learn how it works, and try it yourself in a fun hands-on lab where you'll use CRISPR to delete a gene in bakers's yeast, resulting in a pink color. How far has this technology gone, and what are its implications for human identity and the planet? What are the ramifications of plug-and-play genome editing? We will speculate even as we become part of the do-it-yourself biology revolution.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Painting with Fluorescent Bacteria
description: Have you ever made art with living pigments? Discover how to partner with micro organisms to create pieces that are alive. In this workshop we will create collaborative works using non-harmful bacteria that produce colored and vivid fluorescent pigments. You will learn how to culture the organisms and also how to display the works, including the UV lights needed to properly visualize the fluorescence.

title: HCI or HHI in Live Events and Public Spaces
description:
Share various artists' public installation or artistic designs that encourage Human to Human interaction (HHI) in public events or spaces via technologies, thinking about how HCI or tech influence people's impression and actions at different events or spaces. 

Practice how to come up with the activities that require the interaction with another person in the public space. (A possible short movement game can be derived from theatrical perspectives..)

title: Roll Your Own MFA
description:
In this session we will discuss pursuing education in the arts & technology space through workshops, small programs, tiny schools, summer camps, conferences, incubators, and other part time & short-term opportunities.

For many people professional degrees are out of reach for time, financial, or other practical/personal reasons. However there are many different ways to pursue learning in the arts & technology space outside of degree programs.

In this session I will give a short introduction to the idea of à la carte education and building a school for yourself. I will talk a bit about my own attempts at achieving a self-education comparable to an MFA including some tips & tricks.

Later in the session we will build a course catalog together for a virtual school starting from a base list of educational opportunities and experiences. Participants can add other programs, opportunities, books, movies, and ideas to the list. We will then discuss some of these options and consider how you can put pieces from the catalog together to make your own educational program.

This session is for people who are interested in pursuing further education at the intersection of the arts & technology. Many of the lessons are generally applicable to other areas of self-teaching. 

Class Materials: 
[http://bit.ly/unschoolcatalog](http://bit.ly/unschoolcatalog)

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

title: Roll Your Own Studio
description:
New York is home to some of the best known and most acclaimed creative technology studios at all scales. From smaller studios like Fake Love, Office for Creative Research, and Data & Society to larger brand-name conglomerates - you can find pretty much everything here.

At some point most of these studios were just a couple of people and a contract trying to get started. How did they go from that to world recognition?

In this workshop we will discuss the process of starting your own studio. We will start by discussing the practicalities of independent practice (one-person studio) and tiny studios (a few people). From there we will explore how these businesses can grow and change over time.

Through the discussion we will explore career opportunities in the creative technology space in studios of all scales. Starting your own studio is extremely challenging and for most people the best option is to join an existing studio.

This session is for anyone who has any interest in working independently, starting their own studio or business, or joining an existing studio in the creative technology space. Many of the lessons are more generally applicable outside of creative technology.

title: Coloring with Basquiat (Field Trip)
description:
Field Trip - Off Campus - Weather Permitting

Visit the grave of Jean-Michel Basquiat, hang out, and color with crayons. Located in the historic and expansive [Green-Wood Cemetery](http://www.green-wood.com) in Brooklyn, Basquiat's grave is a mecca for artists who appreciate his work and story. Actually I have no idea who or how many people go there, but this is the third year I've organized this and it is consistently inspiring and enjoyable.

title: This is Your Brain on AI
description:
This is an experimental session for exploring the existential implications of Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning. The goal of the session is to explore how study and use of AI may influence human thought processes.

This session is for people into AI, neurology, psychology, brain science, and psychedelics. It helps to have an appreciation for the writings of Robert Anton Wilson, Timothy Leary, and Aldous Huxley.

**Talk - 30 Minutes** - The session will start with a short talk on the current state of AI and its implications for the future. I will then share stories from artists & scientists working with AI on the changes they have observed in their thinking that seem related to their study. Finally I will wrap up the stories with some wild speculation to set the stage for open discussion.

**Discussion - 60 Minutes** - After the talk we will open the floor for participants to share their AI related stories. We will discuss and explore the rationality and implication of the stories and see what conclusions if any we can collectively reach.

**Background**

A little over a year ago I began to come up to speed with the latest in AI. Having taken workshops at SFPC and ITP Camp on the subject I began studying the technology and experimenting with all sorts of applications. My ITP Camp project last year was a series of interactive paintings made using AI.

After several months of intense study I began noticing changes in certain aspects of my own thinking. It seemed as if what I had learned from studying AI was influencing how my own mind functioned.

A year later, AI has become a central topic of global discussion as it transforms the landscapes of countless businesses. 

A year later, I continue to observe significant changes in my thinking as I study the technology, and I'm increasingly hearing similar stories from other people.

In general I prefer to spend a significant amount of time synthesizing ideas around a subject before giving a talk on it. However this is an area moving so quickly that it feels necessary to begin discussion sooner than later.

title: Revealing Migraine through Art & Science
description:
**In this session we will explore the relationship between Art & Science through the lens of Migraine.** The session is extremely relevant for anyone who suffers from Migraine, but the lessons are applicable to any discipline.

Migraine is degenerative neurological condition experienced by 18% of women and 6% of men on average. While commonly discussed as a headache, Migraine is actually a very complex condition that can disrupt the brain and body in countless ways.

The past 10 years has been amazing for research on Migraine. Scientists have a comprehensive understanding of the condition and new treatments are actively in development that could significantly improve the situation for many sufferers.

That said what the scientists have found could have been discovered sooner had they considered the work of artists suffering from the condition. Artworks depicting the condition going back over a hundred years contained much of what was needed to reach the answers we have today. Yet artwork was dismissed as an input to the scientific process due to its subjective nature. 

Migraine is a perfect example of where the failure of Art & Science to collaborate for cultural reasons resulted directly in human suffering. My hope is that in the future it can also be an example of where Art & Science work together to quickly aid the hundreds of millions of people suffering world wide from this condition.

60 minute talk followed by 30 minutes of discussion.

title: Math in Code 4 Noobs
description: Learn how to use basic trigonometry to make your p5 sketch awesome! In this workshop, we're going to explain the basic theory behind trig functions (sine, cosine and tangent) and harness their powers in code. The first half of the workshop will be a trig review, and the second half will walk you through a few examples that use trig in p5.js. The point of this workshop is to help you understand what's actually going on when trig functions are used in code, and help you feel confident enough to use them yourself! This session assumes no prior knowledge of javascript or trigonometry.

leader_users.name: Melissa Parker
leader_users.about: Melissa Parker has just wrapped up her first year as a graduate student at ITP at NYU Tisch. She is first and foremost an educator, having spent four years as a speech and debate coach at Stuyvesant High School. At Stuyvesant, she has also spent time working as a geometry, trigonometry and english teacher. Before coming to ITP, she worked at an education software startup where she wrote and edited content aimed at teaching science literacy to kids. At ITP, she has developed anti-harassment twitter bots and turned a waterfall into a musical instrument. During the summer of 2017, she will be working as an instructor with Upperline Code and Kode with Klossy. Next year, she will continue to work on projects that fuse feminism, technology and education.

leader_users.name: Jaycee Hermida Holmes
leader_users.about: Jaycee is an NYC based programmer and interaction designer with a background in mathematics.  She has just completed her first year as a graduate student at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. Having recently earned a degree in mathematics from Spelman College, Jaycee now studies the intersection between design and technology in the Interaction Telecommunications Program {ITP}, where she focuses on developing applications for emerging technologies. During her first year, Jaycee was chosen for the 2017 Bloomberg Augmented Reality {AR} Prototyping Fellowship through the NYC Media Lab. There, she is prototyping an interactive data visualization application for an augmented reality interface. Also in her first year, Jaycee became a 2017-2018 NYU Social Sector Leadership Development {SSLD} Fellow, where she explores how technology can be used for social good. In April 2016, she completed a pop-up museum exhibit, presented at the NYU Leslie eLab, highlighting the work of the NYU Law School’s Immigrant Rights Clinic against prolonged detention of those facing deportation. Summer 2017, Jaycee will be an instructor with Girls Who Code, at IBM, an educational summer program aiming to close the gender gap in STEM.  In Fall 2017, Jaycee is excited to complete her second and final year at ITP as she continues to explore the intersection between STEM and social justice.

title: Shader Shakedown: Embracing the Modern Computer Graphics Pipeline
description:
Shaders offer a gateway to harnessing the massive computational power of the GPU. This power brings the possibility for transforming your programmed graphics without hindering the performance. In this session we will walk through the modern graphics pipeline and look at the different applications that shaders can be used for. We will talk through the jargon and look at the boiler plate associated with using shaders in in Processing using GLSL. 

Participants can expect to leave with enough  overview of the modern graphics pipeline and shaders to be able to dive deeper and learn more about this fascinating subject. This workshop also aims to be practical and I hope that everyone will walk out feeling like they have another new tool in their toolkit and can begin learning how to better use it.
tag_list: graphics, shaders, glsl, opengl, webgl, gpu

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: Creative Coding in pure javascript
description:
Learn to create generative and sound reactive art in pure Javascript. 

We'll look at using canvas to create audio visual art. I'll show you my process, and then we'll get down to building our own particle system.

Some knowledge in JS and HTML would be a serious advantage.

=====================================

Creative Coding Workshop Requirements:
 
1. Laptop
 
2. Chrome Browser
You’ll need to have the latest version of Chrome installed [https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/index.html](https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/index.html)
 
3. Development Text Editor
You need to install a text editor. I recommend Atom: [https://atom.io/](https://atom.io/) 
A good alternative to Atom is Sublime: [https://www.sublimetext.com/](https://www.sublimetext.com/)
(but really, Atom is great)
 
4. Live Server:
This is going to make your life so much easier and coding so much faster and fun. For Atom, simply go Preferences->Packages and search and install Live Server
[https://atom.io/packages/atom-live-server](https://atom.io/packages/atom-live-server)
For maximum happiness make sure your default browser is Chrome.
 
5. A basic understanding of the web and HTML:
Again, not really needed, but will go a long way in helping you get more out of the course and make better art.  
 
Here’s two helpful guides:
[http://htmldog.com/guides/html/beginner/](http://htmldog.com/guides/html/beginner/)
[https://websitesetup.org/html-beginners-guide/](https://websitesetup.org/html-beginners-guide/)
 
Also a basic primer in colours:
[http://htmlcolorcodes.com/](http://htmlcolorcodes.com/)
[http://www.computerhope.com/htmcolor.htm](http://www.computerhope.com/htmcolor.htm)

This is a very very helpful Javascript creative coding primer:
[http://www.crunchzilla.com/code-monster](http://www.crunchzilla.com/code-monster)

title: Intro to User Experience Design
description:
This workshop will serve as a basic introduction and overview of the broad field and problem-solving framework of user experience design.

Campers will learn elements of a UX design toolkit, tactics, and activities to better understand people, their needs, and their contexts with the goal of improving or developing new products and services.

We'll be doing some rapid, collaborative design exercises and you'll be introduced to: user research, persona development, user journey mapping, information architecture, pen and paper wireframing, and creating clickable prototypes.
tag_list: user experience, design research, product design, service design

title: Walking tour over Brooklyn Bridge and through the DUMBO neighborhood of Brooklyn.
description: We will walk over the Brooklyn Bridge to the historic section of DUMBO (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass). Visit  3 contemporary art spaces, tour the area and see unusual historic and industrial architecture. We will also walk through the new and vast Brooklyn Bridge Park. Will end at a local bar and/or restaurant. Dinner with the group possible. Group will decide if they want to walk from NYU to the bridge thru Soho/Chinatown, or take subway to Bridge entrance.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

user.about: Currently a UX/Product Designer at MSK Data Products where build digital tools that leverage data and machine learning to prevent, control and cure cancer

user.name: Kirill S
user.about:
I'm a Soviet- Born multimedia artist living in Brooklyn. Seven years ago, after realizing that my personal beliefs had never concurred with the majority of my native country, I moved to America in search of the expression of my feelings, thoughts, and ideas, especially in art and design.

I love computers and Internet. I spend good portion of my day in front of the screen, designing, researching and sometimes just mucking about. Music, hanging out with my friends, snowboarding, soccer, drinking and eating, watching movies, and traveling pretty much sums up the remainder of my time.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

title: Git it Together Parts 1 and 2
description:
So maybe you've never heard of Git, maybe you've heard about Git and want to know more, or maybe you've heard about it a lot and you've even fibbed a little about knowing what it is and now you live a life of lies. Fear no more! Kat will go over Git from the very beginning. 

Don't have a Git account? Don't know how to use the terminal? Do you think ssh stands for simply sitting at home? No problem! We'll go over everything you've wanted to know and then some. 

At the end of the class you will:

Have a project in Github
Alter that project in Github
Alter your friend's project in Github
Know how to deal with merge errors
Create branches
And so much more!!

**It is HIGHLY recommend that you install git BEFORE the workshop. Go here: http://git-scm.com/download/mac.**

title: Machines Learning Movements
description:
What do machine learning, visual art, and motion capture have in common?

Come find out at this workshop! We will first write some code to record skeleton movement with a Kinect or perceptron neuron suit. Then we will record multiple people doing the same gestures. We will then use a python machine learning library to "learn" these gestures, and finally write simple sketches that are triggered by the gestures we taught to the machine.

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

user.name: Berlina
user.about:
I am a hardware maker turned **front-end web developer with specialization in Javascript canvas APi**(p5.js alike). I do contact improvisation in the past 5 years and would like to discover a way to **sharpen our built-in senses**. For me, it is a way to better locate yourself in physical and increasingly overwhelming virtual world. Let's all take a deep breathe together first.  

I have made many different things/prototypes along the way of learning new skills.
I built hypnotized brainwave-interactive light installation(failed!), sound controlled flappy bird to embarrass yourself in public as an ice-breaker, digital scratch card with any amount money your want (thx to generated art), and collaborated with local artists to make Ebay(Chinese version) plug-in to hack product recommendation algorithm and  interactive Facebook wall you can read in an elevator. 

Feel free to check out my work [here](https://berlinali.github.io/work/) and talk to me in the camp.

title: Screen Printing for Curious Makers and Visual Adventurers
description:
Silkscreen printing is arguably the most versatile print medium in the world, with a huge range of applications from fine art to fashion to technology, and countless combinations of all three. It's simple to learn, and allows the practitioner to transfer nearly any substance to any surface in any design. 

This workshop will teach campers how to go from a physical or digital image to a usable screen to a finished print, using a setup and materials that can be purchased for less than 100.00 and employed in even the most cramped apartment.

And we'll make a t-shirt and/or poster for ITP Camp, incorporating images from all participants, so bring a picture you'd like to contribute.

user.name: Vanessa Rosa
user.about: Vanessa Rosa is a Brazilian visual artist and art historian. She creates projects that mixtures public art, community activities, technological experiments and historical research, usually having painting as her main medium. Currently she has been developing a research about algorithmic images and traditional ornamentations from Portuguese, Islamic and West African cultural groups. Vanessa has worked as project coordinator for different organizations and is an illustrator and art director for Viajante do Tempo publishing company. Vanessa has a deep interest in collaboration projects and in understanding other cultures and cities. She has already proposed and participated in mural paintings, exhibitions and other projects in different countries across South and North America, Europe and this year she's heading to Africa for the first time.

I’m a virtual reality enthusiast, avid book reader of all topics, and a lifelong learner. My interests include VR/AR, storytelling, and curious thought experiments about the future of technology. My favorite question always starts with "What if..." and I often try to follow up with the answer.

I create fun and weird experiences that challenge the reality we live in with VR/AR. My approach to virtual and augmented reality is more artistically inclined, with emphasis on experience design.

I’m also an aspiring lighthouse owner, coffee drinker, and writer. I like to-do lists, cats, and people who hire me. Currently, my favorite color is green.

If you’re interested in virtual and augmented reality or collaborating to create an experience, I’d love to hear from you.

title: Autonomous Vehicles... \(0_o)/...LOOK OUT!
description: Don't look now, but autonomous vehicles ("AV's", a.k.a, "driverless cars") and drones are on the road and in the sky delivering gluten-free catering to various VC meetings in Mountain View, and death from above in various locations globally. So, what will happen to our fair New York City? Who needs AV's? What will happen to drunk drivers? Parking lots? Vehicle ownership? Transportation for the sightless? Will I finally get my flying car? Join Towhee Co & JC Fab Lab founder Eric Nadler for a hand's on session of building simple scale-model autonomous vehicles using the Towhee Co. Model A car and some off-the shelf control components from Sam Labs. We'll then spend some time looking at what's on the horizon at the mainstream car manufacturers and at the businesses who are currently thinking about how to create the future with this fear-inducing technology.
tag_list: cars, vehicles, driverless car, autonomous vehicles, drones, robotic cars

title: Joy of Laser Cutting Guided Workshop
description:
The Joy of Laser Cutting workshop will introduce you to the basics of working with laser cutters by walking you through the development of 5 beginner recipes. Through the design and assembly of biscuits, wafers, cookies and crackers, participants will develop a rounded understanding of the techniques that are possible in working with a laser cutter and will have the opportunity to design their own wood or plastic baked goods.

Ideally, participants are artists or creative makers who have not previously worked with laser cutters but are interested in learning. Participants should have some familiarity of Adobe Illustrator and general comfort working with computers. 

This workshop is part of the research work for Alda Escareño’s master’s thesis. Participants will be asked to fill out a short questionnaire after the workshop, and will additionally also receive a couple of questions through email a month after the fact. Participation in the research component of the workshop is voluntary. Participants that RSVP for this session will receive an email with additional information.

Due to equipment and material constraints this session will be limited to 5 people. Please only RSVP to this session if you are definitely able to attend and stay for the entire 3.5 hour session. If anyone RSVP-ed is not present by 5 minutes before the start time, their spot will be given to the next person on the waitlist who is physically present.

We are asking that participants bring their own laptops with a copy of Adobe Illustrator. Please inform the session leader if you do not have access to either.

leader_users.name: Alda Escareno
leader_users.about:
Alda is an artist, designer and maker living in Toronto, Canada.

She is currently an MDes candidate at OCADU. Her thesis work is focused on  connecting artists with new technologies through the power of fake food.

title: Joy of Laser Cutting Self-Guided Workshop
description:
The Joy of Laser Cutting self-guided workshop will introduce you to an online tool that covers the basics of how a laser cutter works, what techniques it is capable of, how you can set up files and how you can combine techniques to create finished projects. A facilitator will be on hand to assist you and to help run files on the laser cutter. 

Through the design and assembly of biscuits and crackers, participants will develop a rounded understanding of some of the techniques that are possible in working with a laser cutter and will have the opportunity to design their own wood or plastic baked goods.

Ideally, participants are artists or creative makers who have not previously worked with laser cutters but are interested in learning. Participants should have some familiarity of Adobe Illustrator and general comfort working with computers. 

This workshop is part of the research work for Alda Escareño’s master’s thesis. Participants will be asked to fill out a short questionnaire after the workshop, and will additionally also receive a couple of questions through email a month after the fact. Participation in the research component of the workshop is voluntary. Participants will receive additional information through email once they RSVP.

Due to equipment and material constraints this session will be limited to 5 people. Please only RSVP to this session if you are definitely able to attend and stay for the entire 2 hour session. If anyone RSVP-ed is not present by 5 minutes before the start time, their spot will be given to the next person on the waitlist who is physically present.

We are asking that participants bring their own laptops with a copy of Adobe Illustrator. Please inform the session leader if you do not have access to either.

title: How will the content creation generation connect with the virtual world?
description: Exciting technologies such as digital fabrication, virtual/augmented/mixed reality, and 3D scanning and 360 video are becoming more affordable and accessible than ever. This presentation will discuss various examples of educational programming developed around these technologies, demo a 360 video from an anti-trafficking organization in Thailand, explore the symbiotic relationship of 3D printing and virtual technologies and discuss the implications of content creation on the future of VR. Attendees will also have the opportunity to be 3D scanned and receive a free file of the scan following the presentation.
tag_list: digital fabrication, VR, AR, mixed reality, 360 video, education, 3D printing, storytelling

leader_users.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
leader_users.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

user.name: Baaria
user.about:
I’m a virtual reality enthusiast, avid book reader of all topics, and a lifelong learner. My interests include VR/AR, storytelling, and curious thought experiments about the future of technology. My favorite question always starts with "What if..." and I often try to follow up with the answer.

I create fun and weird experiences that challenge the reality we live in with VR/AR. My approach to virtual and augmented reality is more artistically inclined, with emphasis on experience design.

I’m also an aspiring lighthouse owner, coffee drinker, and writer. I like to-do lists, cats, and people who hire me. Currently, my favorite color is green.

If you’re interested in virtual and augmented reality or collaborating to create an experience, I’d love to hear from you.

title: Adding spatial audio and other effects to 360/VR content to educate and entertain
description:
I am working on putting together more videos from what we shot last summer in Thailand. I learned a thing or two at SXSW this year about the importance of using "spatial sound" in this medium to direct the user experience. I have yet to learn how to do this and would love to learn by collaborating with anyone interested. Please see" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=06g76keQ8M4
 
Besides educational videos about human trafficking, I have some fun footage of beautiful places in Thailand that I would love to put together, as I believe it's important for people to see that "Thailand is more than trafficking." Please check out this short clip: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SfK6qvqYA-E 
I just started learning about 360/VR last summer, and have been stumbling along, learning as I go. I have a few finished videos, but it would be awesome to work with anyone who knows about this fantastic medium, and to be able to perhaps even pass on what we've learned and created!  :)
tag_list: spatial audi0, 360 video,VR, story telling,  human trafficking, Thailand,

title: Leave your computer at home. Come to Governors Island! Pet goats, feed chickens and help build a compost windrow!
description:
Get outside! See where your food waste goes! Come to Earth Matter (www.earthmatter.org) on Governors Island and help build a compost windrow! We will combine 15,000 lbs of neighborhood-generated food scraps with an equal amount of Governors Island yard waste. Learn about how these organics are processed. Help empty bins of food scraps, remove contaminants (plastics and other non-compostable items), and chop open whole foods to let microbes in.
(It's more fun than it sounds). Then you can play with the baby goats and chickens that live at the Compost Learning Center (their poop is key to making amazing compost). 

You would arrive on the 9 am ferry and return to Manhattan on the 1:30 pm ferry.

Governors Island is a 172 acre island in the heart of New York Harbor. It’s only 800 yards from Lower Manhattan, and even closer to Brooklyn. It is a world unto itself, From 1783 to 1966, the island was a United States Army post, and from 1966 to 1996 the island served as a major United States Coast Guard installation. Now, it's a huge park where you can climb the Hills (hill-y landscapes offering unreal 360-degree views of New York Harbor), chill in hammocks, walk. bike (the island is car-free), see art or attend one of the many cool events that happen there.
tag_list: compost, goats, chickens, log-off, Governors Island, boat ride, field trip, nature

title: Mappathon: Origami Projection Mapping
description:
Mappathon™ is inspired by events called hackathons where computer programmers, graphic designers, interface designers and project managers collaborate intensively on software projects in limited time. 

This 3 hours session goes over the latest projection mapping technology and techniques to students, enabling them to create a site-specific interactive or static projection mapping installation. 

The course has three learning stages: Making animation from static images and mixing video contents, How to create a projection mapping on 3-dimensional Origami pyramid surfaces, and making an installation. 

During all stages, there is a strong emphasis on experiential learning, presentation and sharing, and teamwork. The students will experience the process of an art installation from concept to public presentation, enhancing the students’ artistic development a great deal.

When you sign up this session, the students get 30-day full access to Modul8, MadMapper, and Vezer.

modul8.ch

madmapper.com

http://imimot.com/vezer/

Go to previous Mappathon™ photos here, www.mappathon.com

title: ITPower & Enertive API: Visualizing Real-time Energy Usage on ITP Floor
description:
[ITPower](https://itp.nyu.edu/classes/itpower) is an research group that aims to make the ITP community aware of, and reflect on the energy usage on the ITP floor. In this workshop, we are going to build a simple web application that can visualize the real-time power usage on the ITP floor!

We will use [node.js](https://nodejs.org/en), [express.js](https://expressjs.com), [p5.js](https://p5js.org) and [Enertive API](http://www.enertiv.com) to build the application. So if you would like to know more about how to build a web server, or how to use an API, this workshop is perfect for you. We will explain the basics from the beginning! Check this [repository](https://github.com/ITPNYU/ITPower/tree/master/simpleEnertiv) to know more about this workshop.

title: Document Your Project: How to Shoot and Edit Video for Your Art Project
description:
A workshop discussing how to document your coding/hacking/art project using documentary filmmaking techniques. For instance, you may want to document your project for explanatory, archival, or fundraising purposes.

Topics include how to plan and film broadcast-quality video interviews, ways to cover an event or performance, working with the equipment that you\'ve got, and utilizing social media to build support and interest in a project, with a focus on Twitter and Snapchat.

I\'ll propose some best practices as far as workflow as well.

Examples of well-documented coding, hacking, and other art projects will be shown and there will be some hands on bits as well.

I work with mixed media in my studio, making motorized sculptures powered by solar panels, large format photographs that I paint on, and wearables.  I would like to learn more about electronics, power and arduino. I lived in NYC for many years and now I live in CT.

user.name: Christina Kiritz (Arnold)
user.about:
Hi everyone! 
I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

title: 3D Scan and Print Yourself(And Others!)
description:
In this session, we'll learn how to use Skanect, a free 3D-scanning software, to scan ourselves, and then process the mesh through Rhino so that we can make a 3D print.

A ridiculously simple process, and lots of fun!

user.name: Michelle B
user.about:
My work involves strengthening democratic institutions and increasing the integrity of elections around the world. In my official job, I spend my time helping civil society organizations evaluate whether their elections are inclusive, transparent and fair. Over the last ten years, I've had the pleasure of working with 15 different civil society organizations and helped them to observe more than 25 elections in countries such as Egypt, Georgia, Kenya, Myanmar, South Sudan, and Ukraine.

My unofficial job is to figure out how to tell stories about democracy in new and interesting ways and help civil society activists use new technology to fight political oppression. I've been experimenting with chatbots, 360 video, games, and dabbling with mobile VR.

title: Wearable Design and Prototyping
description: Want to create some wearable projects? Come to the workshop to learn basic wearable design concepts and prototyping methods. This workshop will cover: an introduction to wearable design, basic electronic knowledge for soft circuitry, wearable lo-fi-prototyping and physical computing prototyping methods, and some case studies. Feel free to bring any wearable ideas, WIP wearable projects, and circuits that you want to turn into wearable ones to this workshop to discuss.

leader_users.name: Jingwen Zhu
leader_users.about: Jingwen Zhu is a multidisciplinary designer, creative technologist and maker based in Brooklyn. She just received her master's degree from ITP, Tisch School of the Arts, NYU and became a research resident there. She's currently the technology lead of [Wearable Media](https://www.wearablemedia.studio/). Her recent work involves connected devices, wearable technology and physical interactions. She is interested in designing engaging interactions and combining traditional crafting with innovative technology.

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

user.name: Vanessa Rosa
user.about: Vanessa Rosa is a Brazilian visual artist and art historian. She creates projects that mixtures public art, community activities, technological experiments and historical research, usually having painting as her main medium. Currently she has been developing a research about algorithmic images and traditional ornamentations from Portuguese, Islamic and West African cultural groups. Vanessa has worked as project coordinator for different organizations and is an illustrator and art director for Viajante do Tempo publishing company. Vanessa has a deep interest in collaboration projects and in understanding other cultures and cities. She has already proposed and participated in mural paintings, exhibitions and other projects in different countries across South and North America, Europe and this year she's heading to Africa for the first time.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

title: Getting Started With Soft Circuitry
description: This is an introductory workshop for students to learn the basics of soft circuitry. In this workshop, students will learn electronic basics and soft circuitry basics. Students will get a hands-on experience of building LED circuits, DIY sensors, and sewing with conductive materials.

user.name: Valerie Carew
user.about: I am a multi-disciplinary artist with a focus in textile media, sculpture/ installation and performance. title: Arduino x Web
description:
This is a hands-on workshop to get started with Web Bluetooth LE. The in-class example will use the onboard accelerometer on Arduino 101 to control a p5.js web app wirelessly.

Please bring an Arduino 101 to this workshop. You could check it out from pcomp closet in the shop.

title: Opera at Washington Square Park
description:
After the Launch Weekend Session, come listen to live opera music in Washington Square Park! Co-hosted by my good friend Colin Huggins, a street performer who plays grand piano in the nearby park.

World renowned artists will perform opera scenes from Mozart, Donizetti, Mendelssohn, and more.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colin_Huggins
https://www.facebook.com/events/793720687442913/

We will meet by the elevators at 5 PM, then walk over (two blocks away) as a group. Afterwards we can get a drink at a nearby bar and get to know each other better.

I am a social entrepreneur and tech enthusiast, passionate about social justice with 18 years of experience in human rights education and advocacy using technology (most recently with 360 and VR videos.) I am a lucky ITP alum! I founded Prevent Human Trafficking (PHT) in 1999 to address this heinous phenomenon, rampant in Thailand, Vietnam and Cambodia - and now the US. My professional trajectory was driven by my upbringing in South and Southeast Asia where I was born and raised in a cult, and encountered exploited children daily. I was able to leave the cult at 21.

My expertise has contributed to policy and legislative change, including passage of the original Trafficking Victims Protection Act (TVPA) of 2000. Through PHT, I have helped hundreds of individuals, and organizations and several governments, to tackle the root causes of human trafficking through direct support, technical assistance and using transmedia to educate, document and promote their work. 
I have consulted with over 100 companies, agencies, governments, foundations and nonprofit organizations worldwide, and taken hundreds of people on annual anti-trafficking study tours to Southeast Asia, to learn about the issues first hand, from some of the pioneers of the global movement, who risk their lives daily on the front lines to prevent human trafficking.

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

title: Create 360 Videos in Processing!
description:
Learn how to create 360 Videos and pictures using the popular Processing animation library!

I am the author of Camera3D, a Processing library that extends the functionality of Processing to create all kinds of 3D effects. One of them is for "equirectangular projections" for the creation of 360 video. I will walk you through all of the steps needed to change an ordinary Processing sketch to a 360 Video. Works with Facebook, Youtube, Vimeo, and more!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tZLm1290W5U

I am a hardware maker turned **front-end web developer with specialization in Javascript canvas APi**(p5.js alike). I do contact improvisation in the past 5 years and would like to discover a way to **sharpen our built-in senses**. For me, it is a way to better locate yourself in physical and increasingly overwhelming virtual world. Let's all take a deep breathe together first.  

I have made many different things/prototypes along the way of learning new skills.
I built hypnotized brainwave-interactive light installation(failed!), sound controlled flappy bird to embarrass yourself in public as an ice-breaker, digital scratch card with any amount money your want (thx to generated art), and collaborated with local artists to make Ebay(Chinese version) plug-in to hack product recommendation algorithm and  interactive Facebook wall you can read in an elevator. 

Feel free to check out my work [here](https://berlinali.github.io/work/) and talk to me in the camp.

title: How can we make AI an integral part of the creative process?
description:
This hands-on collaborative workshop will explore how to make AI part of your creative process without being an expert in coding or data science. We will start by breaking down the most common myths and misconceptions about AI, followed by test-driving a new ideation process to help you create radically innovative products and customer experiences powered by AI and data.

Co-taught by Marc Blanchard, Global Head of Experience Design at Havas, and Marc Maleh, Global Director of Havas Cognitive (ITP Grad from 2005).
tag_list: AI, XD, Data, Design, Workshop, Process

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

title: Pure Noise Raspi
description:
This is a crash-course session running sound on Raspberry Pi using Pure Data for Sonic Interaction. A mash-up session for noise, covering different ways of getting sound from Raspi, and a simple Pure Data patch to do wicked stuff. We make a wireless instrument to send data (XBee) to Raspi/Pure data.

Bring:
Raspi 2, 
headphones, 
a USB sound card, (most generic ones work like, adafruit 1475 $4.95) with 3.5mm output
Arduino Nano, Mini Pro or any Arduino + 
2 analog sensors, I use light (adafruit product/1384 ,$3.95) for the demo and a push button, and jumper wires, 

XBee Series 1 pair and a XBee Explorer USB (SparkFun) or XBee adapter (adafruit) (maybe the shop has some?) and a power source such as a 9V battery to power the wireless sensor.

For the Raspi (I use Raspi 2) and Jessie, you will need to power it with USB micro cable, To enter Raspi terminal/OS you will need a small HDMI display (adafruit), USB keyboard/mouse or run it headless USB-Wifi (adafruit)
You will also need to prepare a small sound file in .wav (to make your own sound) in Pure data

I will provide code to download to get you started, both for Arduino and Raspi and some XBee adaptors along. I'm thinking of making a Raspi OS downloadable, alt. copy the OS to some sd cards. I will give you the slides which will provide you with info on how to set it up. 

(You can skip the XBee wireless part and go straight into Raspi from Arduino if you like)
tag_list: Noise, Pure Data, Raspberry Pi, Sensors

user.name: Cousin Marilyn
user.about:
Daughter of The Black Prophetic Tradition, visual artist Marilyn Nance has produced exceptional photographs of unique moments in the cultural history of the United States and the African Diaspora, and possesses an archive of images of late 20th century African American life.

A two-time finalist for the W. Eugene Smith Award in Humanistic Photography for her body of work on African American spiritual culture in America, Nance has photographed the Black Indians of New Orleans, an African village in South Carolina, churches in Brooklyn, and the first Black church in America. She is recognized by the Smithsonian Institution Center for Folklore Programs & Cultural Studies as a community folklore scholar, an individual who has shown a significant contribution to the collection, preservation and presentation of traditional culture in a community or region. Her work can be found in the collections of the Smithsonian American Art Museum, Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, and the Library of Congress.

Nance's photographs have been published in The World History of Photography, History of Women in Photography, and The Black Photographers Annual. Her writing, which often accompanies her photographs, has been published by Aperture, The New York Foundation for the Arts, and the Friends of Photography. She is the recipient of the New York Foundation for the Arts Fellowships in Photography (2000 and 1989), Nonfiction Literature (1993), and the New York State Council of the Arts Individual Artists Grant (1987).

A graduate of New York University's Interactive Telecommunications Program (Tisch School of the Arts), Nance is an African American digital pioneer; she created her "Soulsista" website in 1994, was one of the Internet's first radio disc jockeys in 1996, and in 1998 produced an interactive web site based on an African divination system. Nance served as the Curator of Photography for the Digital Schomburg Web Project, selecting for Internet publication, over 500 images of 19th century African Americans, from collections of the research libraries of the New York Public Library. Additionally, Nance holds a B.F.A. in Communications Graphic Design from Pratt Institute, and an M.F.A. in Photography from the Maryland Institute College of Art.

Nance is a technology evangelist who encourages people of all ages to see themselves as designers, producers, and owners of information. She is currently sharing her experiences with other artists, organizing and protecting her archive, and exploring digital assets management. She is the matriarch of the intergenerational, interdisciplinary art collective, The Santana Project.

title: The Beauty of Stupid Shit: A Brainstorming Session
description:
Join this session where we will embrace the ridiculous, imagine the unnecessary, and discover ways to innovate things that don't need to be innovated. We'll ponder on the use of mining bitcoin as a way of punishing children while encouraging them to learn complex math, experiencing reality virtually, and a password checker that reads out your password among many more! Discover all the useless uses of technology and have fun doing it. 

This session is for everyone, but especially is encouraged for those who need help figuring out an idea to work on this ITP camp.
tag_list: stupid ideas, hackathon, ideation, workshop, brainstorming

title: So now what? How to pitch, brand and sell your big idea
description:
We'll go over the basics of what goes into winning that sales pitch (e.g. when you convince someone to fork over the greenbacks for your brilliant thingie-ma-jig).

We will cover the basics of identity design, packaging and physical feedback, the importance of narrative in a pitch, the bare bones of deck design and tools to PUMP YOU UP to feel bold and confident when communicating how your idea is the bee's knees.

leader_users.name: Adam H
leader_users.about:
I'm a creative taking the summer to transition my career from traditional design to digital practices. 

I've spent the last few years developing brand identities for huge corporations and now I want to turn my attention to more purpose driven work as well as follow the fun I've had with code to develop a more robust skill set.

user.name: Baaria
user.about:
I’m a virtual reality enthusiast, avid book reader of all topics, and a lifelong learner. My interests include VR/AR, storytelling, and curious thought experiments about the future of technology. My favorite question always starts with "What if..." and I often try to follow up with the answer.

I create fun and weird experiences that challenge the reality we live in with VR/AR. My approach to virtual and augmented reality is more artistically inclined, with emphasis on experience design.

I’m also an aspiring lighthouse owner, coffee drinker, and writer. I like to-do lists, cats, and people who hire me. Currently, my favorite color is green.

If you’re interested in virtual and augmented reality or collaborating to create an experience, I’d love to hear from you.

user.name: Noah Pivnick
user.about:
Tech savvy broad-spectrum creative thinker with deep appreciation for the nuance of complex systems, strong affinity for collaborative problem-solving, and a pervasive interest in continual process improvement.

Hoping to use my time at camp to prototype as much of [this](http://www.buk.nyc) as possible.

user.name: David P
user.about:
This is my 5th year as a camper and I'm really looking forward to being a part of te program again. For 20+ years, I have explored emerging technologies that can help brands tell better stories. I was an early pioneer in the use of VR for advertising and marketing, having started with experiential advertising in 1991. Since then, I've run my own lab, the Brand Experience Lab and was the 1st Director of the AT&T AdWorks Lab. I worked on a variety of emerging technology launches, including a VR tour for Cutty Sark in 1993 and the award-winning AudienceGames cinema AR program in 2007.

In those many years one thing has remained consistent: I've looked for innovative ways to create compelling, authentic and relevant brand experiences.

I've been very fortunate to have the chance to travel with my daughter Sydney, who helps me remember that the most important experiences are the ones you share with people you love.

title: Kids Day Planning Session
description:
This will be our first planning session to see who wants to work on a kids day event and look at the schedule to find a date. Let me know if you can't join but are interested in participating. In past years, it has been from 5-8 on a weekday, but the group can decide what's best. 

In past years, campers have created their own activities or worked in small groups to create activities that take 15-30 minutes to do. We've had people demo VR, motion capture, 3D cards (they made great gifts!) and many other things. If your camp project is designed for children, this is a great time to do user testing. 

Please us this form to add your plans for Kids Day - https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1IfpmutmRqfTDMabvT_HyH9XERra0zznb1GVDm3bv28Q/edit?usp=sharing

Pictures from the 2015 Kids Day - https://goo.gl/photos/DN4C9PA4FHZeF29E9

More information to follow!

user.name: Kar Rosen
user.about:
Hi, I'm Kar! And I do a little bit of everything!

My background is in fine art and graphic design, and built props as a hobby. And since finishing my first year at ITP I've also have gotten stronger fabrication skills and electronics. Some of my favorite projects to do are wearables and making your own custom circuit boards! 

If you need help with anything related to general fabrication, PComp, PCB fabrication, need help soldering, or just want to bounce ideas, feel free to find me!

I can't wait to meet all of you!

user.name: Smita Sen
user.about:
I am a UX Designer and a multimedia visual artist. After graduating from Columbia University in 2016, I have served as a part-time UX/UI Design Intern at media giant Discovery Communications, and as a full-time Experience Design Intern with RAAMedia, the media arm of exhibition design firm, Ralph Appelbaum Associates (RAA). I am interested in digital technology as a space to both build solutions and to create art. I am especially interested in how human relationships to analog tools influence interactions with tools recreated digitally.

As an artist, my work has been shown has been shown internationally at Al Serkal Avenue in Dubai, and throughout New York City, at venues like Jonas Mekas' Anthology Film Archives, the Knockdown Center, Heath Gallery, The Sump/Poppers Locarno, LeRoy Neiman Gallery at Columbia University, and Postcrypt Gallery. In 2016, I  was awarded the prestigious Academy of American Poets College Prize for my poem, Emerge. Emerge was thereby published by the Academy of American Poets.

user.name: Daveed
user.about:
Hi! Very excited to be a counselor this summer. I like meeting people, and if I can be of any help in any way, that's the best. I've been in ITP for two years now, so please feel free to ask me anything!!!

I like working with physical materials, but pixels are very useful too. I love talking about ideas, narrowing them down, and improvising to help make them happen. I love the idea that our creations can have a real impact on other people, and I love figuring out how to best make that happen.

I am from Jerusalem, now living in NYC, just completed ITP. I studied screen-based arts, I’ve worked as a newsroom editor, doing education and organizing work for various human rights NGOs and activist groups in Israel, worked in the theater, as a scriptwriter, and as an animator. I am currently pulling these threads together into the arena of playful media-based learning: experiences that can facilitate growth for adults as well as children.

ps . If you have any questions about the laser cutter, in particular, I really love working with it and will be very happy to introduce you some of its wide range of uses.

comments.body: Any possibility that this could start at 8:30 instead of 8 so that it isn\'t overlapping with other workshops?

title: Editing with Adobe Premiere Pro
description: This is an editing workshop using Adobe Premiere Pro. Please download a free 30 trial version of Creative Cloud and Adobe Premiere Pro before class. We will go over the basics of Adobe Premiere for the first half hour to an hour and then we will work on our own edit.  I will provide footage and music so we can practice in class. If interested in editing your own footage, please bring in HD 1920x1080 footage and music.

title: Physigital - Combining the Physical Space with Digital
description:
In this session, I'll review a variety of projects that have combined the physical and the digital to create interesting experiments in the future of space. Everyone is welcomed to bring their projects to review as well. In addition, we can talk about the ethics of overlaying digital information onto the real world, including who controls the information flow and updating "content."

Some links to review as a starting point:

http://thephygital.com/

http://www.pattenstudio.com/

http://blog.polinchock.com/socialization-of-place/

http://experiencemanifesto.blogs.com/experience_manifesto/socialization_of_place/

https://vimeo.com/89712955

https://vimeo.com/39611704

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ihPsvgnagEI&t=1s
