title: Kinect Brainstorming Session
description:
Let's brainstorm projects we can do using the Microsoft Kinect!

 To start working with it, download the SDK here (https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/kinect).

Here are things to read about 
general page for info (https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/kinect/develop)
Some forums (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn782037.aspx)
extra tools (https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/kinect/tools)

Disclaimer, I know basically nothing about the Kinect but maybe by the end of this session we will know many things together. Bring your big ideas and let's have fun~
counselor_comments:
Based on short convos I had with two campers, what I saw through the glass wall, and some words I exchanged with Zoe the session leader, It seemed like this class went really really well! The room was packed, nearly everyone stayed put the whole time, and seemed to be very absorbed and attentive, it looked like the discussion was strong, and I heard heartfelt applause at the end. 

I didn't take any photos. It was just people talking. 

This report by Daveed.

title: Helping you make sense of personal security.
description:
Date TBA

It has become incredibly challenging to make sense of digital security. Often it appears so overwhelming that we end up ignoring the issue altogether. Alternatively we rely on quick fixes or on paid products to handle pieces of it for us.

The goal of this session is to set aside time to identify practical aspects of current digital security for each participant. By the end you should be able to narrow down the scope of what you need to focus on.

This session is not intended for security professionals, there will simply be nothing new or cutting edge. It is intended to help anyone who is anxious about the issue but haven't had the opportunity to make decision about it.

title: Creative Programming with Clojure
description:
[Clojure](https://clojure.org/) is a programming language that is designed to be a practical dialect of [lisp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lisp_(programming_language)).

Many of Clojure's core aspects make it a wonderful fit for creative programming. I will go into what these are, and provide practical examples of their use. 

We will also look at certain programming techniques that can help you maintain sanity while creating complex dynamic systems.

The material will focus on people new to Clojure. If you already know the language, please do attend as well, your feedback would be most helpful.  

If you haven't considered the impact of the programming language on your practice, this might also give you a new perspective.

title: What does everything collect on you and how can you use it?
description:
Here we'll be going through the popular apps and services that people use and highlighting surveillance and data-collection tools and how you can use them to make interesting things (with examples).

Bring your laptops so you can see exactly what your devices have collected about you and sold to advertisers, and what APIs you can use to pretend you're an advertiser and use this data for Art™!

Also will give a quick guide to the Freedom of Information Act and what other date collection tools are being used by your local, state, and federal governments, and some good projects that use them for public good.

title: Intro to making music with Ableton Live
description:
We'll talk a little bit about what makes Ableton different than other Digital Audio Workstations, and dive right in to making a mashup. If we have time, we'll get into some other concepts, like using our phone as a controller.

This class is geared towards Ableton beginners, at any level of musical ability - though hopefully anyone will find it interesting.

You should:

Download the Ableton trial version [here](https://www.ableton.com/en/trial). Do it before class... it's big-ish.

Bring headphones!

Later this week I'll post links here to a few small files you'll need.
